Rene and Georgette and The Late Great Johnny Ace, in my opinion, rate with the best of his songs.", "topic_list": ["Paul Simon (musician)", "Underrated Things or People", "Music Albums", "Pop Music", "Music Recommendations", "Musicians", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "444", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Definitely. Considering all that Paul Simon went through at the time with his tempestuous marriage to Carrie Fisher and the trials and tribulations of touring with Art Garfunkel, it is amazing that he produced such a brilliant album.\nUnfortunately, exhausted by all the events going on around him, Paul did not promote the album so it reached a limited audience.\nFavourite Tracks\nJohnny Ace\nRene and Georgette Magritte\nAllergies\nThink Too Much\nHearts and Bones", "I agree. Adding to those you mentioned, any list of best Paul Simon tunes should perhaps include the title track and definitely include Train In The Distance as well. According to Jeff Giles, it was a flop after Simon left Columbia and went to Warner Bros to release another flop, the ambitious album and movie One Trick Pony. Pony and Bones were sandwiched between the Central Park album. Paul considered including Garfunkel on the H&B album but considered the songs too personal to include Art in the final mix. Apparently Art wanted to record his parts in private in the studio but Paul wasn\u2019t comfortable allowing Garfunkel to take any additional liberties with his songs. Paul has often said that he didn\u2019t get enough credit for Bridge Over Troubled Water; perhaps his greatest hit featuring Art, so it\u2019s no surprise that he told Art to take a hike as he recorded Hearts & Bones. For a deeper dive, read the review by Jeff Giles: Inside Paul Simon's Commercial Slide on 'Hearts and Bones'", "It is my favorite Paul Simon solo album. However, my bias is that I am a big fan of Simon & Garfunkel, but not such a big fan of Paul Simon\u2019s solo work. I\u2019ve listened to everything Simon & Garfunkel, but not all of Paul Simon\u2019s solo work.\nWhen Paul Simon started working on Hearts and Bones it was going to be a solo album. Then he had the reunion in Central Park with Art Garfunkel in September, 1981. It was at that concert that The Late Great Johnny Ace was performed for the first time. (Unfortunately the performance was interrupted a few seconds after the lyric about the death of John Lennon by someone leaping onto the stage and yelling, \u201cPaul, I need to talk to you,\u201d before security threw him off the stage. For that reason the song made it to the video, but not the record album.)\nSimon & Garfunkel spent the next couple of years touring together, during which time they announced that the upcoming album would be their first studio album since Bridge Over Troubled Waters. The album was to be titled Think Too Much. When I saw them in concert during the summer of 1983, they performed four songs from the upcoming album. Simon performed Allergies and Late Great Johnny Ace on his own. Together they performed Think Too Much and Cars Are Cars.\nUnfortunately Simon & Garfunkel fell out again a few months later. Simon considered himself a poet of the times who liked to record his material quickly and while it was still topical. Garfunkel considered himself a perfectionist, not in any rush to put out material until it sounded perfect. Simon got fed up with how long it was taking, and wiped off all of Garfunkel\u2019s material, releasing it as the solo album Hearts & Bones.\nAlthough I was very disappointed that the new album was without Garfunkel, I bought it nevertheless. I found that the album is very much in the style of Simon & Garfunkel, more so than any of Paul Simon\u2019s other solo albums. (American Tune from a previous solo album is also very much a Simon & Garfunkel style song. Although it started out as a Paul Simon solo song, Garfunkel got to sing on it at the Central Park concert.) So I very much like the style of music of Hearts & Bones. In 1951, a computer scientist, Alan Turing, recorded computer-generated melodies. The recording, which was filled with a lot of disturbances, has finally been restored. You can hear the first machine-made music here.\nThe Potential of AI in Music\nThrough the reinforcement learning approach, AI trains itself to analyze different types of compositions. By continuously learning, technology can extract the characteristics and the thesis of music entirely. The final AI model is then created, having the capability to compose altogether different, innovative, and unique musical pieces. Sounds cool, right? But the next AI application in the music industry will blow your mind - AI can write song lyrics too. By training the AI model with a considerable amount and type of dataset containing random lyrics and music compositions, we can obtain AI that independently generates lyrics.\nRecording a song is expensive. AI helps artists record music inexpensively. We have AI apps that record music, assisting independent artists in recording their music.\nAnother area where AI can showcase its talent in music marketing. AI can help marketers to obtain critical information on how to effectively sell a music album to the listeners. By analyzing the behavioral pattern of listeners, AI can gauge the sentiments of users and recommend them songs based on their interests.\nThe Development of AI in Music\nThe level of AI sophistication in the music industry has reached a place where we now see robots entering the mainstream music industry. We know that the potential of AI is assisting humans in the creation of audio content. But, AI is here to replace artists altogether. Did you know, robots can not only create original musical pieces but also play music? Cool, right? In the future, we might see robots performing on stage along with musicians and artists.\nTen years back, we never thought that AI will innovate the industry to an extent it is doing now. Also when I ask for the vocal melody, they assume that is my job which is not cool at all seeing it is their song and seeing I am being paid to be the Orchestrator or Mix Engineer I am not being paid to be the Songwriter. Also if they are as out of tune as they often are, even my DAW is unsure which notes I should be moving to.\nKnow at least the basics of your craft and those around you. I know a guitar has 6 strings starting on E moving in a pattern of 4th, 4th, 4th, 3rd, 4th and that once the low E is tuned, you can fret to tune the rest - despite not being able to play a guitar in any useful fashion myself.", "Is it important? Yes. It particularly helps to be able to play piano, read music and know basic music theory. I think you are more rounded professionally if you do. Does it guarantee success? No. You still need talent.", "Almost. There are a few exceptions, but in most cases you need to be able to play some sort of instrument - with the exception that if you can hit every note perfectly and know where it is in relation to other notes, and are pitch perfect, then you are good to go. However the chances are that if you can do it that well and are that musically talented, you have already learnt an instrument anyway.\nHowever, the other exception is of course music theory. If you have an amazing knowledge of music theory then you don\u2019t need to be able to play an instrument to sing. But yet again, people with exceptional music theory knowledge tend to play an instrument.\nAlso, you will be more useful to music producers and agents if you can play instruments - more likely to get given jobs, in fact.\nSo I would strongly say yes to this.", "Yes. Important but not absolutely necessary. Playing an instrument, even at an amateurish level, greatly enhances a singer\u2019s connection to music-making. Also, you can accompany yourself as you practice singing. And who knows, maybe you\u2019ll want to be able to write songs at some point, freeing yourself from being dependent on the songwriting of others.", "Wouldn't hurt. A basic - prretty much required- if you knew your way around theory fundamentals on a piano. Singing notes from sheet music, understanding chords and inversions and things like what a 7th and a 9th are. The piano (or any keyboard instrument) is the universal center in the common sense.\nIf you wanna-be a singer/songwriter, hows does learning guitar strike you? There are some very clever songwriters. Randy Newman (toy story) does just fine as a singer songwriter on piano. Who knows? Do what works for you. Learn it all.", "Thanx for the A2A Brady. I\u2019m a musician. I can play the Guitar, Bass, Drums, Keyboards and Sing. Started out on Piano when I was around 6\u20138 years old. Hated every lesson. Regret quitting them every day now. I\u2019ve had a few guitar lessons when I was 10\u201311 too and they were just as boring as the Piano lessons. Quit them too, But I didn\u2019t give up on the guitar. I wanted to be the next Ace Frehley or Jimmy Page so I kept at it and learned on my own. Those early Piano lessons taught me one thing, basic theory. Same with the Guitar lessons, they showed me scales and key. None of which I ever used until later in my music career. When I started playing for money and publicly most of the songs I learned by ear FIRST, but I can be an anal bastard when it comes to playing other peoples material. I always seek out the sheet music, tablature or song books to check my chords, notes and phrasing. Also to see the proper tuning since there are ways to play songs written in alternate tunings in standard. Again, me trying to recreate EXACTLY how it was originally done, if it was in an alternate tuning I INSISTED the band play it that way.\nAs for vocals, I\u2019ve always contributed back up vocals in every band I\u2019ve ever gigged with and sang certain songs that were in my range and that I sounded better on. Now that I don\u2019t gig anymore, mostly due to pain issues I do LOTS of recording in my home studio. It\u2019s taken me a couple years, but it\u2019s acoustically treated and I have accumulated some excellent pro equipment (Microphones, Preamps etc.). All that pro gear does NOT make you a better vocalist. Quite the opposite, it shows every flaw more plainly. A great example is the difference between a set of $50us headphones I used to use for tracking and the pair of 250ohm ones I bought when I could afford a \u201creal\u201d set of studio headphones. They revealed all the frequencies and faux pas more clearly. I ended up going back and remixing and in some cases, re-recording entire vocal and guitar tracks. The cheap headphones didn\u2019t allow me to hear the \u201creal\u201d recording. I was thoroughly embarrassed that I shared some of those songs too. If anyone was to listen to them through a decent set of speakers/headphones, they would cringe. I may be exaggerating a bit, but it helps to make my point. Better Gear doesn\u2019t make you sound better. In my opinion you don\u2019t need to be able to play an instrument to be a good vocalist, but knowing your notes, key, scales are definitely a big help. Knowing what key the material you are singing over will help you choose the range and notes to sing over it with. It also helps to be able to tell the band or the studio session artists what key you prefer to do the piece in. If you were to get any professional vocal training, I\u2019m sure it would be part of the curriculum. IF there is any one instrument I would suggest to learn if you are insistent on the subject, I would say the Piano. Which brings us full circle here. I can play songs on the keys, just not by sight reading, but I really regret I didn\u2019t stick with those lessons way back when.", "Critical. Otherwise, they don\u2019t know where the notes are. It\u2019s that simple. The market for singers who don\u2019t know where the notes are is small and glutted. Unless you\u2019re Morrissey or have something like that going on, singing with wandery pitch isn\u2019t going to be something you can make a living at.\nSing something unaccompanied and record it. Then play the song on an instrument a few times. You don\u2019t even have to sing along; just play on it for about 20 minutes. Now sing the same bit as before and compare the two recordings. The difference will be huge.\nThe ability to accompany your own singing casts a long shadow across the rest of your musicianship. Mel Torme\u2019s vocals would never have swung as hard if he\u2019d never played drums. B. B. King would have a different singer if he didn\u2019t play guitar.\nBesides, knowing how to operate an instrument is very instructional for how to operate the vocal instrument.", "Not absolutely necessary\u2014I\u2019ve played with vocalists who had a good grasp of theory and the instruments they work with such that I felt there was no handicap. But\u2026I highly recommend that any vocalist play at least the piano or guitar (or some polyphonic instrument), which will enable them to communicate much more effectively with the musicians in their group, at recording sessions, etc. I consider it akin to speaking the language of a foreign country you intend to visit or live in\u2014kind of a \u201cduh uh,\u201d no?", "I would say, that in my opinion, that it is important. E.g lyric videos, AMVs, etc. What happens usually?", "topic_list": ["Monetization", "Music Videos", "YouTube Videos", "Videos", "YouTube", "Music"], "no_of_view": "277", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["What usually happens is that the fan gets a copyright strike for using that music without permission. Doing this is illegal copyright infringement.\nPossibly that artist already made a deal to give after-the-fact permission to YouTubers. In that case you get a copyright claim. The video stays and you are not punished, but ads are put on it with 100% of the revenue going to the musical artist. I've played French Horn for years, and thought this would be easy, but it is hard to hit the high notes.", "topic_list": ["Bugles", "The Bugle", "Brass Instruments", "Boy Scouts of America", "Musical Instruments", "Music"], "no_of_view": "851", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["As another answer suggested, depressing the keys for valves 1 and 2 will lower your trumpet/cornet to the key of the bugle in the key of G (Bugles also come in keys of F, G, Bb, and C). You\u2019ll get through your merit badge OK. Remember that bugle calls are \u201csounded\u201d and not \u201cplayed.\u201d Your band director should be able to assist in adjusting your horn embouchure sufficient to sound the calls on a Bb trumpet. They will sound better if you do not depress any keys. A Bach 7C mouthpiece (or equivalent) should help. The more keys you depress will lower the pitch, but will make the lower notes more difficult to sound cleanly, e.g., the low \u201cC\u201d in Tattoo, the most beautiful and longest of all the calls.", "A possibility: the requirements say you can use a bugle, a trumpet or a cornet. If you happen to be using a trumpet or cornet, depressing valves 1 and 2 is perfectly legitimate because this puts you in the same key as a standard G bugle. So instead of (written) G atop the staff, you would be playing an E a step and a half lower. Not quite so high.\nI had the honor of playing taps on a trumpet for a deceased friend after years of not practicing. This got me through it.\nYou can even use all three valves as long as no one notices. Different mouthpieces can help with high notes also. A more shallow cup, or a smaller diameter cup size aids high range. Good luck.", "(A2A) You need to develop a trumpet embouchure to play bugle. Given that the highest note of a bugle call is generally the F at the top of the staff, that\u2019s not very high \u2014 we\u2019re not talking \u201cscreamer\u201d here.\nYou need to strengthen the corners of your lips, so you can press them together and slightly toward the center: this is where you should get tired. You also need air support, the ability to raise the back of your tongue while lightly touching the tip to your bottom teeth, and the ability to slightly curl your lips back. All of this is very small, gentle, and subtle.\nI recommend you find a trumpet teacher and work on your embouchure with that teacher."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Milo Miller", "view_list": [123, 189, 130]}, "834": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Eileen Am", "Stephanie Metzger"], "question_title": "Why do I cry whenever I hear a song that was significant for my parents (ex: wedding songs)?", "topic_list": ["Crying", "Songs", "Emotions", "Music", "Personal Question"], "no_of_view": "575", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Because you Love your Parents.\ud83d\udc68\u200d\ud83d\udc69\u200d\ud83d\udc67 \u2665\ufe0f There must be a fond deep down memory or something your grateful for that they did or went thru. {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Bruce Wilson", "Saibal Sen"], "question_title": "Is sheet music the same for all instruments?", "topic_list": ["Sheet Music", "Musical Instruments", "Music"], "no_of_view": "225", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Treble clef is the same for everybody. Bass clef is the same for everybody. Piano uses both (at the same time!), higher pitched instruments use treble clef, lower pitched instruments use bass clef, violas normally use the dreaded alto clef, bassoons and trombones sometimes use tenor clef. Vocal music sometimes uses a perverted tenor clef which is an octave below treble clef. Concert C in flute music is a written C, but a concert C in clarinet music is written as a D because the clarinet is a transposing instrument. And there are a lot of transposing instruments that don\u2019t play in concert pitch.\nSo no, not exactly. It\u2019s like we all kind of speak the same language, but with funny dialects. Band and orchestra directors have to be able to translate to talk to each group. Composers and arrangers have to know all these little quirks as well as the usable range of each instrument. It\u2019s a little complicated.\nOn the other hand, all the rhythmic functions are the same. A quarter note gets one beat in 4/4 time for everybody. Vocal music sometimes breaks up eighth note groups into single eighth notes so the right syllable can be printed under the right note. Sheet music pretty much all looks the same, but there are subtle differences.", "Mostly not. If you go to any authentic site you will find different instrumentations for \u201ca particular\u201d tune."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Faruque Hossain Piyada", "view_list": [8, 24]}, "218": {"no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Who is the singer of the song \"Memories\" (start from 0:00) in the video?", "topic_list": ["Maroon 5 Songs", "Maroon 5 (band)", "Singer Identification", "Singers", "Videos", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "19", "create_time": "Apr 26, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Quora User", "view_list": []}, "456": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Valerie Quinn", "Christopher Smith", "Joseph Baldassarre"], "question_title": "What are some tips for getting better at counting odd time signatures?", "topic_list": ["Tempo", "Time Signatures", "Rhythms (music)", "Signatures", "Music Theory", "Music"], "no_of_view": "402", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 6, 0], "ans_list": ["I can only suggest doing as much of it as you can, and playing a lot of music just to play through, not practise.\nHere's an idea. Get a miniature score of something like a Tchaikovsky ballet, or suite from one and choose a percussion instrument that plays frequently.\nFirst take a passage, work it out and practise that. Put in faint pencil marks. This can be a pencil on a newspaper. Now listen to that section, playing with recording. That would probably be quite demanding.", "I take it you mean time signatures with changing numbers of subdivisions? Yeah, those are a challenge. First of all, they are not common. We see 4/4 and 3/4 and 2/4 (and their compound siblings, 12/8, 9/8 and 6/8) all the time, and they are REGULAR. If you only listen to radio pop, you have probably gone five years or more without ever hearing a time signature that ISN\u2019T 4/4, so getting used to something different is tough.\nI had a young Romanian immigrant in my jazz composition class who kept bringing in these compositions in 7 and 9 (and NOT 3+3+3!) and the other students were having a heck of a time reading them and getting them played down properly. He was chuckling in the back as we struggled.\n\u201cWhat\u2019s so funny?\u201d I asked him.\n\u201cEvery nine-year old in Romania can play these rhythms, and some of the most talented musicians I\u2019ve ever met here at school can\u2019t even get through 8 bars of it!\u201d he said.\n\u201cWhy can the nine-year olds play them so easily?\u201d I asked.\n\u201cBecause they all know the dance.\u201d he told us, quite reasonably.\nWe all stood up, put our arms over each other\u2019s shoulders in a line and he taught us the dance step for the 9/8, involving step, step, step, hop (2+2+2+3). We had it in about three minutes. He was right; it wasn\u2019t difficult at all.\nWe sat down at our instruments again and absolutely nailed the living tar out of it. Now WE were the ones laughing at how difficult we had made it before, but it was actually easy once we knew the dance step.\nNow, some of those composite time signatures outside of folk music are made up and don\u2019t sit well. The ones based on actual human music always sit more easily. But you can find the \u201cdance\u201d in any time signature; it just takes a bit more time. That\u2019s what I suggest.", "I think of it this way: there's just duple and triple, so 5/4 is 3 + 2 or 2 + 3, 7/4 is usually 2 + 2 + 3, 11/4 is usually 3 + 3 + 3 + 2, etc.."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Matthew Kalb", "view_list": [12, 98, 12]}, "41": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What is a \"flagalong\" as in the song \"Boobs-a-lot\"?", "topic_list": ["Holy Modal Rounders", "Breasts", "Song Lyrics", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "95", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Earl Kliethermes", "view_list": []}, "759": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Matt Scrabis", "Joe Feelfonk"], "question_title": "Are jazz drummers always thinking about two or four bar phrases when comping?", "topic_list": ["Jazz Musicians", "Drummers", "Drums", "Jazz Music", "Musical Instruments", "Phrases", "Music"], "no_of_view": "383", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [2, 1], "ans_list": ["No. Proficient jazz drummers are thinking about the form and melody of the song, and how their playing can swing while supporting, challenging, and inspiring both the band members and the audience. K-pop is a group-oriented environment, so let\u2019s focus on genres that highly benefit from bands and groups. I\u2019m not just talking about rock music, you also have pop groups, R&B groups, rap groups, EDM groups and so on. Regardless of the genre, if someone is a fan of a band/group, they will have at least one member they see as their favourite.\nBias - the term itself - does have a similar meaning in the West, but outside K-pop, we don\u2019t really use \u2018bias\u2019 to describe our favourite members. Just think about how awkward it would be if you told your classmates that Quavo was your Migos bias, they may not have a clue what you\u2019re talking about. Likewise, we replace \u2018bias wrecker\u2019 with second favourite, because well, imagine how things would go down if you said Takeoff was your bias wrecker.\nSo yes, fans of other genres do have biases (and bias wreckers). It\u2019s just that \u2018bias\u2019 and \u2018bias wrecker\u2019 are simply K-pop terms used to describe favourites within groups and bands. It just comes down to how you talk about your favourites. If your friends are into K-pop as much as you are, feel free to use \u2018bias\u2019, even when referring to non-Korean groups and bands. This is really for purposes of sketching or short score, and I wouldn't recommend it for a conductor's score \u2014 though most conductors prefer transposed score anyway. I believe someone once mentioned to me that Samuel Barber used C clef for horns in short score sketches, but I have no idea if it's actually true.", "Parts are never written in the C clefs (alto, tenor, and others) for horn.\nSometimes, in order to avoid too many ledger lines below the treble clef, horn parts will be written in bass clef for short passages. There are TWO different conventions for that, one of them stupid and confusing (the sounding notes transpose a fourth UP instead of a fifth DOWN like you do in treble clef) and deserves to die in a fire. The other one is reasonable and is the only one you should use in modern music.\nIf you are a professional horn player, though, you probably know which composers used which system (notwithstanding composers on the cusp, like Stravinsky, who changed his mind a couple of times about which convention he was using in bass clef). If you are writing a modern edition of historical music, you should retain the original notation, because everyone knows it.", "Many orchestra players, faced with parts in D, G, Eb, C, etc. that they have to play on their horns pitched in F, will imagine one of the C clefs to facilitate the transposition (I have never been able to do that fluently and have always used the interval method). But as for horn parts actually being written in C clefs, I have never encountered one. They are mostly in treble, with occasional bass clef in older music for low pedal tones."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Clement Ng", "view_list": [44, 58, 24]}, "784": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Sarah Elliott"], "question_title": "Who sings for Troy Bolton in HSM 3?", "topic_list": ["Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "412", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Zac Efron's\nThough he starred as Troy Bolton in the franchise, Zac Efron's voice can barely be heard in any of the first movie's songs. 0], "ans_list": ["There is very little to no demand today. I played full time for years. I don't think I could find the work now. There are tons of musicians around and very few places that use live music anymore. I am a fairly decent amateur pianist; today, in my late 70s, I still take weekly piano lessons (via FaceTime in this time of crisis). I have a Ph D in music history from UC Berkeley. And I am absolutely awed by what jazz musicians can do.\nIn order to play jazz, you must have a deep knowledge of music theory and have a vast range of repertory ingrained in your being. You must be able to compose on the fly. You must also have the ability to play collaboratively in a group. These skills are non-negotiable for a jazz musician. We have trained for many hours per day since as young as 5 years old. We excell at different things.\nThat said, I could go on for hours on why classical is better than pop, but that\u2019s another answer.", "Underestimate in what sense? There\u2019s so much that pop musicians do better than classical musicians.\nI actually feel the reverse a lot of the time. Let\u2019s talk about how many hours I\u2019ve trained in music for: obviously, I trained a lot as a kid, and then I went to college for four years in music composition and then I did two graduate degrees. Then I went and spent two more years at the Lindemann program at the Met (kind of the opera equivalent of medical residency) before starting the fancy international phase of my career just before age 30. That\u2019s a lot of years of work to put in.\nI bring this up because, when a mostly-self-taught pop guitarist takes the position \u201cwhy do classical musicians always underestimate me, we\u2019re both musicians,\u201d I often wonder what he thinks I was up to for 10 years of my life. I spent TEN YEARS more studying this thing, which our pop musician friend wants to wave off with a simple \u201cwe\u2019re both musicians,\u201d so who\u2019s underestimating whom?\nThere\u2019s so much that pop musicians are capable of that my friends and I suck at. You see, somewhere along the way they lost the point of making music, and just got caught up in some age old processes. They are usually insecure because although they pour time, and energy into their endeavors, nobody actually cares about what they do. They are usually slow and have a piss poor work ethic. I will tell you right now, the best food I've ever eaten came from poor, uneducated people who sold food out of their house or a damn food cart on the street for extra cash. Nobody cares what you went to school for. Show me something or shut it up is my attitude towards those kinds. Prince might be compared to him that way.\nBeethoven was known for slaving over his pieces, never satisfied and constantly revising them in the middle of the process, before committing them to performance. But the results were very strong. Maybe Michael Jackson could be compared to him in that way.\nBut the worlds of Mozart and Beethoven don\u2019t exist any more, and never will. So people asking \u201cwho is the new Beethoven?\u201d will never get a good answer, any more than you could answer \u201cWho was the Kanye West of 16th century Italy?\u201d"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Giro Peterson", "view_list": [60]}, "964": {"no_of_follower": 6, "respond_collected": 9, "name_list": ["Michael Rosenzweig", "Frank Mileti", "David Postle", "Richard Rosen", "Robert Holm\u00e9n", "Jacopo Proietti", "Holden Caulfield", "John Hagelbarger", "David Levy"], "question_title": "Classical music is excellent, but how difficult, actually, was it to compose? Beethoven took a while to write his sonatas. Who says that the average pianist, given 30 years, couldn\u2019t write something similar? (Stupid question, but genuinely curious).", "topic_list": ["Classical Music Composition", "Pianists", "Ludwig van Beethoven (composer)", "Classical Composers", "Composers", "Music Composition", "Classical Music", "Music"], "no_of_view": "2,489", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 1, 13, 4, 0, 3, 0], "ans_list": ["A composer is a composer. A pianist is a pianist", "If that were the case more musicians would do it.", "Good composers like any other artistic endeavour are partially formed by their environment. We live in a completely different world to Beethoven, so the world will never see another Beethoven. That does not mean to say, that there are no composers today whose music will not be considered as important as Beethoven's, 300 years from now, but only time can tell. In any case, any such composer's music will likely be completely different to Beethoven's.", "It\u2019s not a question of difficulty, it\u2019s a question of talent. If you\u2019re great at something, it probably isn\u2019t difficult for you, but it may be virtually impossible for most people. The average musician couldn\u2019t compose like Beethoven no matter how much time they had.", "Modest academic composers could write something similar to Beethoven now because they have his examples to study and imitate, so it is hard to assess how genius they are. Beethoven already did the hard work of discovering what sounds great.\nAFAIK Beethoven wrote most of his works in a fairly timely fashion. A big chunk of his income was from selling music for publication so there wasn\u2019t an incentive to dawdle.\nA few great works may have gestated for a long time but he seems to always have had another project to turn to if he got stuck on one. I don\u2019t detect any long periods of inactivity\u2026\nList of compositions by Ludwig van Beethoven - Wikipedia\nTen years elapsed between symphony 8 and symphony 9 but he did a boat load of other things in that time.\nHe has 35+ solo piano sonatas alone, that is like one for every year of his adult life. That is where a modern Beethoven imitator would fail. You could write one sonata that might be viable but could you write 35 that don\u2019t all sound way too similar?\nThe striking thing about Beethoven is he kept changing. Each symphony after the second sounds quite unlike what came before. The ninth doesn\u2019t sound like the eighth, which doesn\u2019t sound like the seventh, which doesn\u2019t sound like the sixth\u2026 And yet they do sound like Beethoven.\nThat is a real trick to keep re-inventing your style and yet keep it. This is several grades above composers like Stravinsky or Copland who ran out of gas in middle-age and began cranking out awful twelve-tone music. Or Philip Glass who has not changed in 50 years.\nOther composer were faster than Beethoven. Bach, Handel and Vivaldi seem to have composed as fast as their quill pen could move across the page.\nConcerto movement by Vivaldi\u2026", "As a composer that's a question I have to face daily. How could I even compare myself to such masters of their craft. It all seems easy (or easier at least) from our modern point of view, but still few can achieve that.\nThere are many things to consider. I think that a decently skilled composer with a very good theoretical background could write a symphony in the style of Beethoven in half if not a quarter of the time that it took for Beethoven himself. Does that make them as good or even better than him? Absolutely not.\nBeethoven pushed the limits of what was acceptable in his time, trying to satisfy both his artistic hunger for innovation and the expectations of the public. What today sounds standard in the past may have sounded revolutionary. Also someone today would probably be aided by computers, softwares and could have access to a huge amount information in just one click.\nThis makes it sound impossible to compose in the 1700/1800's but we have to consider the fact that many of them were following pre-made schemes (Mozart especially, which is why he was so prolific) and they were fully immersed in the aesthetical canons of their era. Beethoven probably took so long to finish his pieces because he had to completely reinvent these \u201cready-made\u201d schemes.\nBriefly, to answer your question, a skilled composer could compose a Sonata in the style of Beethoven in probably 1/2 months (just guessing), but that doesn't make him better and to be honest would be just a waste of time. You have to follow or reinvent the canons of your time, just like Beethoven did, and then MAYBE you could compare yourself to the masters of the past otherwise you'd just be a forgotten imitator.", "How \u201caverage\u201d? How \u201csimilar\u201d? How \u201cexcellent\u201d?", "He might be able to do something similar, but it wouldn\u2019t be nearly as good.\nAnd it isn\u2019t easy to be even mediocre as a genuine, completely trained classical composer. You need to know difficult technical things about music - things that most pop musicians don\u2019t even know exist - and have them so completely internalized that you no longer even think about them when you\u2019re composing, so completely that it just comes out stylistically right. These are matters of form, pacing, development, and harmonic structure, and they aren\u2019t obvious or easy to learn as thoroughly as you need to learn them. Furthermore, they don\u2019t really appear in any other kind of music, at least not at that level of rigorousness. Imagine having to learn a new language - Latin, say - and actually know it well enough to become a great writer in it.\nJazz may be the hardest kind of music to play, but classical music is the hardest kind to write.", "It can take years to write a major composition. On the other hand, Tschaikovsky wrote his very popular Piano Concerto No. 1 in something like a month! So there\u2019s no hard and fast rule!"], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Sean Johnson", "view_list": [1, 4, 137, 36, 470, 118, 5, 111, 121]}, "471": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 6, "name_list": ["Bradley E. Drury", "Abigaill Baker", "Mark Andrews", "C Dorcey", "Don Helgeson", "James Benson"], "question_title": "Why is my hearing bad? I used to listen to my music through my headphones at medium volume and that was loud enough, but recently I can\u2019t hear anything on half volume, it sounds normal when on max volume, what\u2019s going on with my hearing?", "topic_list": ["Loud Noises", "Hearing Loss", "Listening to Music", "Ears", "Hearing", "Headphones", "Sound", "Audio Equipment", "Music", "Health"], "no_of_view": "642", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["Either your ears are getting plugged up or you have damaged your hearing. Go get checked out for an ear cleaning and/or hearing test.", "Go see an audiologist and get your hearing checked.", "The obvious answer is to get the problem checked out. I' m not a medical doctor and you shouldn' t seek a diagnosis from anyone who isn' t. It might possibly be something as simple as a wax build up, in which case your GP would probably either suggest ear drops or that your ears be syringed. That is NOT a diagnosis, however! Just a suggested possibility.", "I hate to bring you the bad news, but it seems apparent that you are losing your hearing, possibly permanently. You should see a doctor to be tested. You may need to stop listening to music entirely to preserve what little is left of your hearing.\nI used to listen to the radio at what I thought was a safe, comfortable level, but then noticed a high-pitched imaginary sound as I lay in bed at night (\u201ctinnitus\u201d). When I realized that this was a sign of damage, I turned the volume control on my radio all the way down, totally, so that I couldn\u2019t hear any music, and noticed that I could STILL hear the internal hiss of the amplifier. I had been playing the sound louder than I really needed to, just to cover up that hiss. To fix it, I put an attenuator (at least 10 dB) in the line between my receiver and headphones, so I couldn\u2019t hear the hiss anymore. (Yes, this wastes 90% of the power coming out of the amplifier, but I don\u2019t care. It cleans up the hiss.) Now, I can hear the sounds clearly even at very low levels, and my ears are working better.\nI have three attenuators. One is a 1000:8 transformer, with the 1000-ohm side going to the receiver and the 8-ohm side to the headphones. This is actually pretty efficient, since the receiver doesn\u2019t need to pump high current through the low headphone impedance. Another is a box of pi-network resistors with bypass switches, so I can select the amount of attenuation I want. The third is an in-line stereo volume control that just splices into the line between the receiver and the headphone plug.\nOur ears, when they\u2019re working properly, can adapt to low sound levels by becoming more sensitive (just as our eyes adjust to darkness). After you put your headphones on, wait a minute or two before turning on the sound, then turn it up slowly until it\u2019s just loud enough to hear. Then back it off a bit, wait a moment, and see whether your ears become more sensitive. If so, back it off some more!", "IT IS EITHER THAT OR YOUR HEARING IS GOING BAD!\nGet a hearing check soon!", "You have destroyed hair cells in your inner ear by listening at high volume. It\u2019s COOL to be able to do that! Some musicians never develop the skill to play anything that isn\u2019t in written form in front of them. There are names for musician\u2019s like this. They have their place. And I highly admire a musician who reads fluently enough to be able to play in an orchestra, etc.. Highly admirable. Certainly you can recall themes from TV shows you haven\u2019t heard since you were a kid. Probably even sound them out on an instrument and be half-assed right. Same thing with songs on the radio or jingles from ten years ago. Compared to your non-musician friends, you can instantly recognize a bafflingly large amount of recordings from anywhere in the song.\nLooking for a sense of normalcy about your personal nature seems like a Quixotic quest. Cross", "Fred Garvin", "Jerry Whalen", "Brian Wilshire"], "question_title": "Does black vinyl sound better?", "topic_list": ["Vinyl", "Vinyl Records", "Sound", "Music"], "no_of_view": "781", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["I have never know that to be the case.\nThe majority of my vinyl collection is black vinyl because that is the default. But, I do collect lot of color vinyl. People will say there is a difference but I cannot hear it.\nThe quality of the pressing itself, not the color, has a lot more to do with the sound if you ask me.", "It\u2019s thought that carbon black, being a powder, could make black vinyl more grainy. Some pressing plants have tried different formulations using liquid dyes. You may sometimes notice that a black record is slightly transparent? This is the result of using a liquid dye.\nBeyond these concerns, however much they actually matter, the color of the vinyl should have no effect upon playback. A record works by vibrating the needle. In other words, it\u2019s the shape, not the color of the record that matters.\nThe thing that\u2019s good about black vinyl is that you can see any dirt or damage quite easily. In fact, I just plunked down big bucks for a hard to get record, and I\u2019m feeling a lot of trepidation about the fact that it\u2019s on clear vinyl. Did they really rate it correctly? It\u2019s hard as hell to see what\u2019s going on with clear vinyl. It\u2019s the worst in this regard. I\u2019m not a huge fan of colored vinyl for this reason. You can\u2019t easily see when it\u2019s dirty or scratched. In that sense, you could say that black vinyl is better for records.", "I think black vinyl does not wear as much as color vinyl or picture disks because it is harder. I have no actual proof of that though.", "It is not the colour of the vinyl. It is its quality. And not all black vinyl sound good either. It is the quality of the vinyl (plastic) compound itself that can be questionable.\nIn a not very distant past, most produced vinyl records were quite good. Eventually, the global energy crisis imposed changes to the manufacturing process. The music industry used to rely on expensive petroleum for vinyl production. To cut costs, many labels reduced the thickness and quality of their materials and Instead of using the original better quality vinyl, they began using recycled materials. They would remove the labels from old records and the vinyl was then melted down and reused. Because of this procedure, even some bits of paper were sometimes embedded in the compound. RCA Records attempted to convince buyers this was a big innovation in vinyl production and branded these new records as Dynaflex. But the truth is that the quality of the product became worst.\nEven today, many audiophiles are convinced that 180-gram grade vinyl records provide a richer audio experience than the lighter, standard grades because of its weight. But that is not the reason. Yes, the 180g LPs may be more \u201cstable\u201d on the turntable platter thanks to their \u201cadded\u201d weight, but the truth is that the quality of the sound derives from the higher quality of the vinyl compound itself.\nColoured records are made of lower quality PVC and, they do in fact, tend not to sound as good even when compared with the lighter, standard vinyl grades. Almost without exception, coloured vinyl discs will have more noise and hiss compared to their black counterparts. Also, other steps in the production process, such as mastering and the pressing plant\u2019s quality control standards, can have a substantial impact on playback.\nPicture Discs tend to be even worst because they are typically made of 3 layers. A first layer being a clear record with no music, the second the picture layer, and the third a transparent very thin malleable plastic layer which contains the grooves. This type of record manufacturing process usually negatively affects both the playback quality and its long-term durability. But, on the other hand, it looks cool and many collectors still seek it.\nToday, most vinyl records are made of transparent PVC. Titanium dioxide and other additives are mixed in to give it a specific colour. For example, the common black colour is achieved by adding black carbon, which also strengthens the PVC compound. This is another reason why audiophiles prefer the 180g pressings because those are made with the original higher quality vinyl used in the \u201cold days\u201d.\nYou should follow the link below for the interesting history of the vinyl record throughout the years:\nPhonograph record - Wikipedia", "Some people believe that colored vinyl doesn\u2019t sound as good because vinyl is naturally translucent and the particles in the colorants distort the sound when it\u2019s played. Accordingly, most reference albums are white or translucent because of this.\nBut if there\u2019s a measurable difference, I\u2019ve never seen it. Or rather, \u201cheard\u201d it.", "I don\u2019t know if black vinyl has a different texture or if coloration can affect the quality of the tone. Back in the late 60s, there was a great album by Dave Mason, Alone Together, that was made with swirling colors and that didn\u2019t affect the quality back then. I think 5 decades record technology might have found its mark somewhere along the line.\nP.S. Look up Alone Together and give it a listen. There is a lot of great music on that album.\nDig deep and enjoy!", "How long is a piece of string? The blue and red records in my collection sound every bit as good as the best black vinyl. However, in the USA many black records over the years were manufactured from recycled vinyl \u2014 paper labels and all. They sounded as you would imagine a rough cardboard record might sound. German pressings, in my opinion, were the best quality, way ahead of the American product."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Robin Coile", "view_list": [36, 83, 1, 137, 79, 94, 43]}, "1051": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Todd Gardiner"], "question_title": "How can I download free music from YouTube to my iPhone?", "topic_list": ["Downloading Music", "Free Products", "iPhones (product)", "Downloading", "YouTube", "Music"], "no_of_view": "346", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["You cannot legal do that. Judging by the reaction of the crowd,they gauge and build their sets around that initial reaction. So if it's a hiphop or trance or techno song that gets the crowd wild,the dj will spin another few similar tracks and in-between that,the dj will tease the crowd with something different to gauge the reaction and energy again.\nMost djs specialise in one particular genre while to a lesser extend some djs play anything and everything. The speciality djs seem to be more successful because they are only known and hired at specific events in which he or she is highly regarded and kn some cases,even revered,musically speaking ofcourse! Lol", "28 year old DJ here, been doing it since 18 and I find myself DJing a bar, club, or wedding at least 2\u20133 times a week as a side job.\nI\u2019ll make this as simple as possible by breaking it down into a few key points. Because you can probably google search it, but you get a lot of information you don\u2019t need.\nYou don\u2019t have to read people like a book\u2026 there are a lot of other factors you can look at to determine an energy level and what you should play. For instance, the time of night, the venue/demographic, size of the crowd, and caliber of the sound system and lights.\nDancing, if people are dancing there is obviously some good energy. You can really tell if crowd is vibing off of a song by their dancing, and if they start slowing down or stopping, time to hurry up and mix into the next one because you are losing them\nGoing back to #1\u2026 even if you are the best DJ in the world you won\u2019t be able to turn it up to 100 let\u2019s say if your a 9pm slot at a bar, or at a wedding during cocktail hour. It\u2019s up to DJ to realize what energy of music to play appropriately.\nDJs also have ability to build energy or take it away. Building energy is up to DJ via increasing tempo, and harmonic mixing, and mixing well and seamless at that. Taking away energy is beneficial in certain scenarios, like you can tell when your crowd is tired if the room is hot, and you\u2019ve had them jumping for 45 min straight. Play a singalong, some slow hip hop, letting people walk away to get a drink and cycling the crowd isn\u2019t a bad thing.\nAt the end of the day It\u2019s harder to control the energy, and play towards the right energy level than it is to read it.\nHope this helped!!!"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Ethan Jenkinson", "view_list": [11, 18]}, "1037": {"no_of_follower": 7, "respond_collected": 8, "name_list": ["Daniel Baker", "Danel Fentone", "Jade Kim", "Favor Mulalira", "Hellevator Agust", "Zara Goyal", "Aspry Wright", "Pierce Brower"], "question_title": "If you were to take one K-pop Quoran to a concert of a group/soloist that's of your choice, who would the K-pop Quoran and group/soloist be?", "topic_list": ["K-Pop", "Quora", "Hypothetical Scenarios", "Music"], "no_of_view": "2,272", "create_time": "Sep 15, 2019", "upvote_list": [11, 15, 8, 27, 8, 11, 19, 25], "ans_list": ["BTS:\nUser-13661653214857033000 (close friend)\nKrenda Seiler (close friend)\nAubrey Saccio (says she\u2019s not a fan, but that she wants to be. It\u2019s very different from standard guitar technique, and metal players use tapping as an add-on to standard technique.\nHe has made a detailed effort to explain it, which starts here:Getting Started with the Touch Technique\nLike everyone, I was blown away by when he was starting out, and I was really impressed with the possibilities, so I tried to learn it, but I didn\u2019t get very far.\nThe thing is it\u2019s very different from playing guitar in the regular way. It\u2019s so different that there\u2019s not a much of regular guitar technique that carries over.\nIt\u2019s like learning a new instrument from scratch, And it\u2019s a really quirky instrument.\nEven though it\u2019s a guitar, it\u2019s not set up like a regular guitar. You don\u2019t even hold it like a regular guitar. and of course you can\u2019t pick it the way you pick a guitar.\nI actually had better luck fooling around with the Chapman Stick, which was actually designed to accommodate the two handed fingering technique (the body of a regular guitar gets in the way). If you\u2019re gonna go for touch playing, that would be my suggestion.\nHere\u2019s an explanation from Emmett Chapman:\nHome of the Chapman Stick", "At least similar", "In principle, you are generally correct. It\u2019s all tapping. But what Jordan does is miraculously complex. You\u2019re aiming very high! But why not try for it? It\u2019ll be a good learning experience, and who knows \u2014 you might become very good at it.", "You\u2019d be better off studying Stanley Jordan. One other thing you should know about Jordan\u2019s approach is that s/he tunes his guitar entirely in fourths, eliminating the half-step shift between the G and B strings. This increases the symmetry of the fretboard across the strings. That might be something that you want to look into at some point if you decide to go deep into what Stanley Jordan does.", "While I don\u2019t have the most experience with electric guitars or tap, I suggest that you do start with the same way metal players tap.\nWith my limited knowledge, I can at least give you a (I forgot what the word was).\nThis is like learning to play eighth notes the classic way then learning the swing/\u201cjazz\u201d way. While I\u2019m not sure if this is your best bet, this is what I would do if I were trying to achieve the same goal.\nHappy learning!\n-Sammy", "Absolutely! Tapping like Stanley Jordan might take a few years but I am sure it will be a good technique to add to your current guitar inventory. One of the prime techniques for playing fast is playing slow and very meticulously. As you move forward you just naturally find your mark. When you train your hands to go on autopilot, you want to make sure that every move is precise. That is what separates the die hard-players from those who want to be die-hard payers. My general credo is to play at my projects as intently as I work at them.\nSometimes I get sidelined by other projects but when I sense that I am losing ground, I snap right back to business.\nI think that a jazz-based motif blended with finger tapping would be a wild ride.\nHave fun and go for the burn!\nGood luck!", "A little yes, but mostly no.\nYes, the technique of sounding individual notes by tapping is the same as metal players do, but what they do and what Jordan does are different.\nUsually metal players tap one note at a time to create arpeggios on one string or extend scalar lines.\nJordan taps whole chords and basslines with his right hand while going on contrapuntally with his right.\nIts a fairly sophisticated approach, very similar conceptually to playing piano. . .which shouldn\u2019t come as any surprise because Jordan was a piano player before starting up with guitar. A lot of the guys who play like Jordan (eg Chapman Stick players) have piano background or approach the guitar that way.\nThere are metal/rock players who do relatively sophisticated tapping. Animals as Leaders guitarist Tosin Abasi does a bit more than usual Van Halen style tapping.\nFormer Megadeth guitarist Chris Broderick (who happens to have a degree in classical guitar) does a four finger on fingerboard type tapping which is pretty involved.", "Not really. Most metal tapping is a single-note melody line that consists of scales and arpeggios. Jordan\u2019s tapping usually features a bass line, chords, and melody line that move somewhat independently of one another rhythmically, and often in opposite directions simultaneously.\nSo the individual taps are the same as far as how you make the sounds, but the musical structure is very different. Metal tapping is a lot faster, but Jordan\u2019s has a more intricate structure."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr Tempo is measured in beats per minute (BPM). That means that a composition that is played at MM 60 has beats going past at the rate of one per second, and a composition at 120 has beats going past at the rate of two per second, and so on.\nThe pulse is the succession of beats. The pulse in 4/4 time is simply \u2018one, two, three, four, one, two, three, four\u2019, whereas the pulse in 3/4 is \u2018one, two, three, one, two, three\u2019 and so on.\nWithin the framework of the pulse, different rhythms can be played, which each have a mathematical value (whole, half, quarter, eighth, sixteenth and so on). The combinations of rhythms (and their rests) are played in such a way that they should make for an interesting and musical pattern, and they must fit mathematically into the framework of each bar, or measure (the space between two bar lines; in 4/4, that\u2019s a total 4 beats a quarter each, or one whole note, or two halves, or eight eighths, or 16 16ths, or any combination thereof that adds up to the four quarters). An example would be a quarter note, a quarter rest, a group of two 8ths, and a group of four 16ths. Together, that would add up to 4 quarter beats.\nCheers", "The pulse and tempo are the same thing, generally speaking.\nThe rhythm is the melody.\nThey tie in. A rhythm sounds best at a certain tempo.", "Pulse refers to the pressure wave generated by myocardial contraction, as felt by palpating an artery.\nRhythm refers to the pressure wave being generated and appreciated in a regular or irregular pattern by myocardial contraction again which can be felt by palpating an artery.\nTempo refers to the pace of the rhythm over time either fast, slow, or usual, again appreciated by palpating an artery."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Roksana Parvin Yasmin", "view_list": [707, 162, 415]}, "1013": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Sarah Elliott"], "question_title": "Who sings with Gavin Rossdale?", "topic_list": ["Singers", "Musicians", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "776", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["A band named \u201cBush\u201d as far as I can tell."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Vita Lea", "view_list": [1]}, "12": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "How come music bass is more intense from far away rather than up close?", "topic_list": ["Sound Engineering", "Bass (sound)", "Bass Guitar", "Sound", "Music Industry", "Music", "Physics"], "no_of_view": "116", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Bhavin Patel", "view_list": []}, "486": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Can you download Google Play Music on iPhone?", "topic_list": ["Google Play Music", "Downloading Music", "Google Play", "iPhones (product)", "Music"], "no_of_view": "208", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Jose Abarca", "view_list": []}, "764": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Who is penguinz0? So many artists from Bufflao Springfield to the Eagles to Black Sabbath to Van Halen to assorted pop acts have gotten bent over by record industry types. It\u2019s all available for anyone to check up and find out about,all the sordid history.Does no one remember VH1\u2019s Behind the Music?\nShe foolishly signed a bad deal that let these entity have control of her Master\u2019s .Now, she\u2019s rerecording old albums. If she and her parents had been smart,this wouldn\u2019t be needed."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Jose Abarca", "view_list": [56]}, "867": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Jonathan Kurtzman"], "question_title": "Why did Taylor Swift lose her songs?", "topic_list": ["Taylor Swift Songs", "Taylor Swift (musician)", "Musicians", "Celebrities", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "597", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["You put things in a sock drawer and they move to the back and you forget they\u2019re in there.\nTaylor didn\u2019t lose her songs. The rights to them are owned by the music label. That has been the typical way the music business works: the record company builds its value by investing in artists - promoting them, financing their recordings, arranging production, arranging tours, etc. - and in exchange one thing they get in return is ownership of the material made. That is not different from what happens in most companies when you create something for the company: you are working essentially on their dime, so what you make is owned by them. Companies have sued people saying they developed this or that product on company time, so the company owns at least a portion of that work.\nVisual artists face a similar problem: they make something on commission, and then it becomes more valuable, and is resold, but the artist gets nothing of the increase in value. It\u2019s been a problem with galleries: they may finance an artist, advancing money for example, on future sales, and then locking in work at a price so anything above that level goes only to the gallery. People do things for money. The old saying in more complete form is not that money is the root of all evil but that love of money is the root of all evil. It\u2019s a version of power corrupts.\nThe record label apparently offered a deal: Taylor could obtain ownership of old material by delivering new material. That was an attempt to persuade Taylor to sign a new contract. I don\u2019t pretend to understand the intricacies of the music business, but I know contract negotiations. Record companies build value to be sold to larger record companies. That\u2019s how you cash out: you either get sold or you buy others and get bigger. There is a simple reason: your business relies on acts, meaning performers, that have cycles of popularity. There are exceptions: some labels have, for example, specialized in relatively low return issues of smaller scale or historical acts. The same is true of publishers: there are some publishers that have existed - don\u2019t know about today - making relatively small money off a handful of perennial sellers that allow them to issue some other relatively small sellers. And of course, many labels (like publishers) remain small because they never happen to obtain or discover an act like Taylor Swift.\nIn negotiating terms, since that is what I know, signing Taylor to a new deal would make the record label much more valuable to its owners. Otherwise, the main assets of the company are and would be the records that Taylor made \u2018for\u2019 that company. I\u2019m not sure why they offered a path to ownership which required a new record to release ownership of an old record. In negotiations, that to me would signal something bad: why not give Taylor everything right away in exchange for a new contract? Why not agree with Taylor that the ownership would only be sold with Taylor\u2019s approval? I have no idea what occurred, but the sensible thing for the record company to me as a negotiator would have been to say: we want to sell you and we need you because you\u2019re the value here. Again, people tend to lose their way when money is involved.\nInstead, they sold the record company to someone Taylor would not approve. But they seem to have received a lot for it, so that path seems to have worked for them. I say \u2018seemed\u2019 because they apparently either were unaware or lost track of the fact that Taylor has the contractual right to re-record the old music later in 2020. Unless there is a claw-back, the new owners either made a valuation mistake or they decided to take the risk anyway. It\u2019s hard to tell because that requires knowing the financing terms. A claw-back is what it sounds like: it\u2019s relatively common for deals to include a re-evaluation of the price based on economic performance.\nI note that Taylor\u2019s cooperation has real economic value. For example, built into copyright is that rights holders have to be \u2018cleared\u2019 for use in a commercial. Or a movie. That\u2019s an income stream you don\u2019t get if you don\u2019t have a cooperative relationship.\nI also note that Prince fought a version of this battle. And John Fogerty fought a version of this battle too: refusing to play Creedence Clearwater Revival songs for a decade or more. (I heard John on the radio say he was at Robert Johnson\u2019s grave in Mississippi when he found himself wondering who owns the songs.) John was so screwed by his label that they actually put another name on as songwriter alongside his, so he has had to share the money he has made as the songwriter with someone who had no role in songwriting. The Beatles dealt with this: Only A Northern Song is a toss-off written by George to fulfill their legal obligation to Northern Songs, which they hated for a variety of reasons, including that their music rights were sold without their permission.\nThe music business has never been particularly nice to artists. They\u2019ve largely followed the model of the movie business, which is famous for accounting practices that make many economic interests a joke: you get paid above a line or you never get paid because big hits never make money below that accounting line. Artists would find not only were the labels lying to them about how many records were sold, literally cheating on royalty statements, but that they were charged exorbitant rates for studio time, for the cost of tour support, etc., all plus interest, so they\u2019d owe the record company money after producing a hit. The record labels would justify this by saying an act might produce a hit, but would rarely produce a string of hits where the power relationship would shift."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Jose Abarca", "view_list": [118]}, "519": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What are some similar songs to \u201cYes I Know\u201d by The Pack A.D.? Now as a lead singer and bass player, I only practice for a little while, about an hour, most days.\nWhen rehearsing or getting ready for a concert I practice a lot more and when recording in the studio I also practice a lot more.\nSo\u2026. to answer the question, it was hours of practice, meeting with pro\u2019s to give me tips and trying to play things i couldn\u2019t, for hours and hours each day, until I could!\nThat\u2019s what took my guitar playing to the next level.\nJD", "To be honest, the answer is easily me. I fell into my own trap which is very common I think. When I struggled to learn something, I would go back and just play what I already knew. That did help me to get better but it did nothing to help me make progress. Keep challenging yourself and pressing forward. I would learn songs and that satisfied me to an extent. But I would ignore songs with chords I didn't know or barre chords. Once I allowed or challenged myself to grow, I did.", "I was at a stalemate with my playing. I was a vocalist, using the guitar for rhythm. I was a pretty good player, using only a pick, and had a adequate chord vocabulary. My voice began to age and fade and so guitar was pretty bland, although it still sounded good due to my acquired skill with diverse rhythms. But I felt I had no where to go and everything was just the same O same O and boring. I decided to do or die with my playing. I determined that for one year, I would play nothing that I had learned before, that I no longer could use a pick, and I needed to play both lead (as in voice) and back up rhythm simultaneously. Also, I wanted to expand my chord knowledge on extended chords and different inversions. Quite a plateful. I made a list of ten songs I wanted to do and dug in. The only song that was from the \u2018old\u2019 me was Country Roads, but now I had to substitute notes for my voice. To shorten this up, the beginning was frustrating and slow going. Fingerstyle was like a foreign language. But eventually I nailed it down pretty good, and with all the practice and song learning I reached the level where I can learn a new song more quickly and better. I have a large repertoire of songs now and can play for hours without any repeats. I always felt that if people were listening to me, they would rather hear songs, preferably ones they\u2019re familiar with, than listen to me play a mess of licks, and riffs, and speed drills. I know if I\u2019m listening to someone play, its\u2019 a complete song, done with excellence that hold me glued. Go to YouTube and pull up Gabriella Quevedo and listen to her play. This is my style, although she is better than me. But that doesn\u2019t deter me. She\u2019s fantastic and inspires me to get better. What makes us better? Practice and more Practice. One of the ways wind players do this is called \u201cmulti-phonics.\u201d For example\u2014if a trombone player plays Bb an octave and a step below middle C, and can hum the F directly below middle C, the resulting overtones will produce a D, albeit a weak one. Different methods of playing pitches, such as smears, ghost notes, glissandos, etc, also help determine the harmonic movement of a piece. I would also say one of the most obvious for the vocal performer in an ensemble is the bass part. Often it does not sound the root of a chord\u2014more than likely it sounds the third or the seventh if if is a seventh chord.", "There is no such thing as \u2018normal\u2019 music theory. Music theory contains descriptions of structures in relation to all music throughout its existence and throughout different developments. As such, music theory can be discussed in relation to different styles (Middle Ages, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Impressionist, Expressionist, Modern, Serialist, Jazz, Popular, and so on) but it\u2019s all music theory. Some styles are more complex than others and require more detailed study in terms of music theory. As far as popular genres are concerned, jazz music theory is probably the most advanced. However, structures in jazz theory are discussed in the same or similar terms as they would have been in the Baroque period: inversions, the role of a rhythm section, construction of melody, rhythms, time, seventh chords, tension and resolution. The jazz language has developed in a way that does treat dissonance differently, and one could discuss that, but so did serialism (Sch\u00f6nberg et al).", "Jazz theory is more modern and advanced.", "Depends on the Theory you are talking about. If it's the music theory you learn in college with 4 part harmonies. (Bass, Baritone, Alto, and Soprano). Then it's pretty different.\nIf it's Theory as in what's a triad, key signatures and etc. Then all that knowledge applies and then some. Jazz involves bigger chords and extensions such as 9th and 13th chords. It also involves different chord progression such as Major and Minor ii-V-I progressions. It can also involve more scales where classical music is mostly Major or the 3 types of minor scales. Jazz can involve pentatonics, whole tone scales, blues scales, diminished scales, and modes.\nGood luck!\n-Blake", "It doesn\u2019t. A Triad is still a Triad in Jazz.\nIt is just that in Jazz there are certain ways of doing things that are worthy of noting as different than from say \u201cClassical\u201d.\nTechnically there is absolutely no reason that we could not have Metal Theory, Reggae Theory, Country Theory\u2026 But they are generally a bit redundant as they are based so wholly on Jazz, Blues, and standard Music Theory that there is little need to create whole bibles on Drop D tuning, emphasizing the backbeat, or 8th triplet rhythms.\nJust as we don\u2019t have whole tracts on pointing your trumpet at the ceiling when you get to the loud bits or solo. These things are just performance variants on what is otherwise same-same."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Spiro Cromwell", "view_list": [303, 329, 7, 287, 314]}, "261": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "How did Interscope Records make money if they never owned the masters of the music the released?", "topic_list": ["Record Companies", "Record Labels", "Music Industry", "Music", "Money"], "no_of_view": "124", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Vaughn Thiel", "view_list": []}, "414": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Shirley M\u00e1rquez D\u00falcey"], "question_title": "How do I add songs to a collaborative playlist on Spotify?", "topic_list": ["Spotify Playlists", "Playlists", "Spotify (product)", "Music Recommendations", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "266", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["This answer is for the desktop application and the Spotify web player. Freebird was a track I learnt on the guitar back when I was first playing and was one of the first and only pieces of slide guitar I\u2019ve ever practised.\nWhen cover bands gig it\u2019s pretty common for people to ask for their favourite song in the interval. In fact ones pretty common for people to cone up to and start chatting about this while you\u2019re playing, which is really annoying - don\u2019t do it.\nMost people who don\u2019t play instruments seem to have little understanding of how things work. Some seem to think that every musician knows every song by heart.\nI remember about 15 years ago being asked to play Bring Me to Life by Evanescence at a gig. I apologised and said we didn\u2019t know it. \u201cReally?\u201d said the punter. \u201cYou\u2019ve never heard it? It was huge a couple of years back!\u201d\n\u201cNo, I\u2019ve heard it. I just don\u2019t know how to play it,\u201d I replied.\n\u201cOh,\u201d said Punter. \u201cDo you think you could give it a go?\u201d\nLikewise, a band I was in who specialised in doing 90s Britpop were asked often to play perennial favourites from the 70s, like The Boys Are Back In Town, which - although a great song - didn\u2019t fit our set at all.\nBands spend a long time rehearsing and deciding their set and image. Punters turn up at a gig and want their favourite song. Sometimes the two things don\u2019t tally.\nWhich brings me to Freebird. It was a popular song in the 70s and an audience of people who like American guitar-based 70s rock will know it. Most of these will be people in the 50s snd 60s so if that is your audience they may well want to hear tracks like that.\nReading comments on the Facebook group there are tracks that repeatedly get asked for at gigs, but these seem to vary depending on the country. Many American bands moan about the repetition of playing Wagon Wheel because people request it. I\u2019ve never heard the track and only know if its existence through these Facebook groups. As a British person playing in groups I have never been asked to play Freebird. Not even as a joke. I have never seen a cover band play it in the U.K. I\u2019m sure many do, but I\u2019ve never seen it. England", "view_list": []}, "758": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Fernanda Machado", "Julien Bourgeois", "Kuba Silkiewicz"], "question_title": "How can I keep my hand relaxed while playing a fast song on the piano?", "topic_list": ["Playing Piano", "Learning Piano", "Pianos", "Learning to Play Musical Instruments", "Musical Instruments", "Music"], "no_of_view": "552", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["You should practice focusing both on the small movements between the notes and the big ones that will drive you through the words and sentences.\nWhile playing slower exaggerate their amplitude. You\u2019ll just need to shrink it down to play it faster.\nWith a clear musical idea in mind, fast trained thinking, and the correct movement practice, you\u2019ll be able to play without tension and enjoying the whole process.\nHave fun with your piano, and let me know if I can help you any further.", "I\u2019m actually working on Debussy\u2019s Passepied\nand Bach Prelude and fugue in c minor\nand it brought me to enquire about hand tensions too.\nIn a few words the name of the game as far as my understanding goes is to practice in the way of the minimum necessary tension and to embed micro release in between tension as much as possible.\nTo do that, the whole body posture have to be involved so that the \u201cresting\u201d state of the body is the closest as possible as the \u201ctense\u201d state of the body at every moment.\n_________\nI found that video on youtube that is helping me a lot to correct tensions especially in my 5th finger. The shaking exercise is giving me great result!\nJosh Wright\nhave a very good channel regarding technic all in all.\n_________\nThen on a more general level I wasn\u2019t familiar with the Taubman\napproach a few weeks ago and it is now definitely in my mind in every practice.\nSome people on youtube will obviously be better than me at explaining :\n_________\nHope this help!", "Oh man, trust me you are not alone in this issue. This is one of the biggest unsung obstacles all musicians face, in my case it's the guitar, but when I played piano primarily, it was there too.\nTension in the hands playing fast pieces is a double edged sword, firstly it is a physical hurdle, strength and fitness that needs to be developed, and the best way to develop that is simply by playing fast alot, but never sacrifice correct technique and musicality for speed. If you cant play it right fast, bring it back a notch til it's right and then get it up to speed again. To play fast, you just have to play fast. Don't buy into the age old myth that \u201cif you can play it slow, you can play it fast\" no. The mechanics of your muscles works very differently at speed.\nOk the other big tension-maker is your psychology. When you play faster, you tense up. More than is necessary. We all do that til we overcome it. To overcome it, firstly you need to know the music intimately, that you dont have to worry about playing the righ notes. Stressing about a possible mistake popping up any second will tense you up. Get that right first.\nLearn to relax your hand beyond what it is at rest. If full tension is level 10, and your resting state is 5, practise getting it relaxed down to below 5 when you're watching TV or whatever. Then when you play again, use that same process while you are playing. That will help bring it to a more manageable tension. It takes time though. You're physically changing the musculature of your hand as well as your psychological state. It doesn't happen fast, but the progress is noticeable as you go so dont give up. It will come."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Rebecca Smith", "view_list": [100, 97, 82]}, "832": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Why would the Beatles release Lady Madonna instead of Across the Universe considering the Anthology version was superior?", "topic_list": ["Madonna (musician)", "The Beatles (band)", "Pop Music", "Musicians", "Music"], "no_of_view": "175", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Danny Robinson", "view_list": []}, "891": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Starlit Official"], "question_title": "How long does it take before you start to miss music?", "topic_list": ["Musicians", "Music"], "no_of_view": "164", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["For me it only takes a few hours, but that's just me"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Rajesh Ammasiraj", "view_list": [61]}, "593": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 11, "name_list": ["Anonymous", "Bruce Epstein", "Rae Hoey", "Sandy Smyth", "Scott MacDonald", "Walt Borys", "Andrew Jonsson", "Robert Reeks", "Juris Klavins", "Gary Sargent", "Albert Brzozowski"], "question_title": "If band names were literal, who would be the most exciting to see live?
