Here are the steps:\n(1) Download and install VB-Audio Virtual Audio Cable\nGo to VB-Audio software website and download the VB-CABLE Driver\nYou would receive a zip file, unzip it and run setup file:\nVBCABLE_Setup_x64.exe (if you are using a 64bit system)\nVBCABLE_Setup.exe (if you are using a 32bit system)\n\nNote: Right-Click on program name and choose \u201cRun as Administrator\u201d\nFollow steps and when it is done, restart your system.\nThis is actually a device driver that will add two virtual audio devices to your windows:\nCABLE Input: this is a virtual playback device that will act as one end of a virtual audio cable\nCABLE Output: this is a virtual Recording device that will act as other end of the virtual cable\n(2) Setup your Sound Devices\nPress WIN-R to open a new Run window\nEnter: \u201ccontrol mmsys.cpl sounds\u201d on the command line (enter only what is within \u201c\u201d); this will open your Sound Settings window\nChoose CABLE Input and then click on \u201cSet Default\u201d button to make it your default playback device.\nNow switch to Recording tab, and do the same for CABLE Output and make it your default recording device.\nWhile you are there, choose CABLE Output, click on Properties to open its properties page then switch to Listen tab: Make sure that the \u201cListen to this device\u201d is checked and the \u201cPlayback through this device\u201d is set to \u201cDefault Playback Device\u201d as shown:\nWhat you have done is that you have connected your Playback device to a virtual microphone called \u201cCABLE Output\u201d, from now on, everything you play on your computer will be directed to this virtual microphone! Then don\u2019t surprise if you playing something and not hearing anything from your speakers\u2026 but wait\u2026\n(3) Setup your Zoom Audio devices\nWe need to make sure that your Zoom audio devices are set correctly so that it is listening to our virtual mic (CABLE Output) instead of normal mic.\nPlay some music in your computer and while it is still playing,\nLog in to the Zoom client and click your profile picture then click Settings\nClick the Audio tab\nIn the Microphone section, make sure that the CABLE Output is selected as microphone\nYou should see the mic is picking some input. This is actually your song that is playing on background, you can pause it and replay it to see it is true.\n(4) Test it\nCall one of your friends to Zoom to test if it is working\n(5) Switch to normal mode\nYou can always change these settings to normal by simply opening your Sound Settings page again and setting back the Playback device to Speakers and Recording device to Internal/External Mic.\nThis procedure should work for any other kind of video or call conference or web streaming services.\nYou can use this during a virtual party or actual parties that people wearing headphones.\nIf you found this answer helpful, please spread word about our app NikooPlayer by simply sharing this post on your social media. To be honest even channel switching amps don't sound that good with their master volume turned down too low. Amps always sound good when they're cranked up.\nA better alternative is to use a reactive load box or attenuator. It not only lets you attenuate the overall volume of the amp but also lets you crank up the amp. Using a reactive load box also lets you crank up amps that don't have master volume.\nIf your amp has an onboard half-power switch then you can switch to half-power mode. Doing so lowers the headroom of your amp lets you crank it up at low volumes.\nAnother thing you can do is to use speakers that have low efficiency rating. Doing so will reduce your overall volume too.", "Rock\u2019n\u2019roll answer? Put all those knobs at 11, play some Pantera songs and wait few minutes till policemen knock down your door. Beforehand, have some knacks prepared for them, they\u2019ll love it!\nEducated and polite neighbour-friendly answer? Use a reactive load box.\nIt absorbs all of the power coming from poweramps without the need for a cab as the resistance, so you can turn it to 10 and it will act as if it were a cab with speakers, with the difference that there is no cab and speakers.\nThen you can attach your favorite cab, and control the output from the load box, feeding the cab.\nThis way you have your amp running at max volume, while being really quiet, but it has a Con: it doesn\u2019t feel like a really cranked amp. But let this to the elitists who think that putting a tube screamer into the preamp is cheating.\nIndeed, you actually can put a tube screamer without having to pay for an (expensive) reactive load box. Again this is not like a cranked tube amp.\nAnother way is to have a Kemper/Fractal hi-gain profile running into a poweramp + cab. Again, this is not for elitists and you\u2019re free to use the setup that most serves to your songs.", "Many many amps have only a volume control.\nMany man newer amps have a gain control and a volume control.\nthe gain control will increase the preamp distortion sound..\nthe volume control will push the power tubes into overdrive.\nYou can\u2019t overdrive preamp tubes and get the same sound. usually described as a crunch.\nthink of preamp sound pushed hard as sand pouring down a metal slide.\nyou know. fuzz!\nthink of overdrive sound as power tubes pushed and gravel sliding down a metal slide.\ncrunch!\nSo. you can\u2019t. You can fuzz it out if you have a gain control.\npush the gain up, set the volume low. and there you go.\nZZTOP!\n(ok only sorta)\nsomething you can do to get closer is look at your speaker specs.\ndb sensitivity. the lower it is, the harder the amp will have to work to get loud. So a low rated db sensitivity amp will give you overdrive at lower volume.\nThe other way is usually done with a pedal. they are overdrive and distortion.. you can choose. best to try them out, or search pedals with sound clips.. maybe at the store or on you tube.\nI build my own amps and pedals so I\u2019m good to go.\nTWANG", "If your amp has a MASTER KNOB: Turn Master on 0. Turn input Volume on 10. Very slowly Turn up Master knob.", "Mr. Adams went through my bag of tricks on this, but one thing I don\u2019t know as I haven\u2019t bought an amp in 40 years is this, and it may be one more way and maybe someone on the board can confirm:\nI have noticed that a lot of amps now come with several power settings i.e. a 50 watt amp will have a full power setting a 25 watt, a 10 watt, a 5 watt and a .5 watt setting. I am wondering if you can saturate the tube when it is at a .5 watt setting at a much lower volume and if that is the whole point of the settings.\nSorry to answer your question with more questions, but it is all about learning in the final analysis.\nCheers", "The majority of tube amps have a Vol/Gain knob for each channel, then a Master vol. For an overdriven sound you crank up the channel Vol/Gain and turn down the Master volume - even single channel amps such as the Fender Blues Jnr have this.\nThere are some amps without a Master vol eg. the Fender Pro Jnr just has a Volume and Tone, which is a budget step too far. In this case you\u2019d have to get the overdrive from a pedal such as a Tubescreamer.", "You either need a tube amp with a master volume which lowers the gain into the power amp (so your preamp does all the distortion but output is low) - this requires an amp that has a preamp voiced for this, e.g. Mesa/boogie, or it could sound harsh/unpleasant. Alternatively you can add a power soak between the amp and the speaker. Or get an overdrive pedal, but then the tone comes from the pedal not the amp."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Shreya Mehta", "view_list": [2, 38, 27, 2, 32, 51, 54]}, "1042": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Cindy Readerson", "Hiim Matter"], "question_title": "If the K-pop idols' height and weight change, will it be changed in the official profile?", "topic_list": ["Idol", "K-Pop Idols", "K-Pop Artists and Groups", "K-Pop", "Music"], "no_of_view": "544", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 1], "ans_list": ["The height will probably change, especially as most idols that change height are seen as shorter than the industry\u2019s standard, and their height might already be slightly exaggerated on the profile anyways. \u0434\u0430\u0432\u0438, \u043d\u0435 \u0434\u0430\u0432\u0438\u2026 \u0412 \u043a\u043e\u0442\u043e\u0440\u044b\u0445 \u0442\u0430\u043a \u043c\u043d\u043e\u0433\u043e \u0438 \u0437\u043b\u043e\u0431\u044b \u0438 \u0431\u043e\u043b\u0438, \u0412 \u043a\u043e\u0442\u043e\u0440\u044b\u0445 \u0442\u0430\u043a \u043c\u043d\u043e\u0433\u043e \u043b\u044e\u0431\u0432\u0438!\u2026\u201d", "The \u2018new\u2019 old Russian imperial anthem adopted in 1991 made little sense anyway. \u2018God, save the Tsar!\u2019 sounded like a joke in historical context.\nAs for the Soviet anthem it had a melody among the best of all anthems although the communist lyrics made little sense.\nAll in all with new lyrics the resulting variant was best comparing to both previous ones.", "Same rhythm? It\u2019s the exact same song not just rhythm.\nWhy would I find it strange if it was something that was planned and not coincidental.\nIf you ask me how I feel about it? Initially I was repulsed by the decision, then accepted and now I love it. Why? Because it\u2019s an absolutely kick ass tune. Besides, Germany still uses Deutschlandlied.", "It was Putin\u2019s decision to change the lyrics of the Soviet anthem and adopt it as the new anthem for Russia. After he came to power, Putin set off to \u201crebrand\u201d Russia and distance it from Yeltsin\u2019s Russia in both locals and foreigners\u2019 perception. This new Russia was an independent hegemony, a political and military heavyweight. For Putin, one of the ways to restore Russians\u2019 pride in their country which had been weakened in the \u201ctough 1990s\u201d was to remind them of the glory of the country they were citizens of until only a decade ago - the USSR. As one of the ways to do it, Putin opted for adopting the Soviet anthem as the new Russian anthem by changing the lyrics.\nHow do I feel about it as a citizen of another former Soviet Republic, Azerbaijan? Honestly, I am not very much fond of it. After the collapse of the USSR, newly independent states agreed to recognize Russia as the successor of the USSR. That is why Russia inherited the USSR\u2019s seat in the UN Security Council, the nuclear weapons program of the USSR etc. However, outside the former Soviet space, one important point is always missed: While Russia was indeed the core of the USSR, still they weren\u2019t interchangeable. While all Soviet nations recognized Russia\u2019s primary role, for them, back then and now, the USSR and Russia are not equal. Equaling them is ignoring other Soviet Republics and nations. This distinction is missed in the West. Therefore, I and many other people feel offended when we are told in the West that our countries were \u201cpart of Russia\u201d. The USSR was different from the British or the French Empires, and from the Tsarist Russia as well. Communists had relegated Russia\u2019s role. Therefore, when Russia adopts the Soviet anthem, for me, it seems unfair to adopt the anthem of a country that was made up by many states - not just Russia. There have been concerns over Russia taking to itself almost all the credits for the Soviet\u2019s victory in WW2. This issue evokes a similar irritation. We do not want to go back to the USSR but all that belonged to it are the common heritage of all former Soviet nations - not just Russians even though they were kind of the \u201cbiggest shareholder\u201d. Yet, they did not have all the shares.\nAlso, of course, this step at the time sent signals of neo-imperialist ambitions of Russia to restore the USSR. Obviously, this is unwelcoming for many in the former Soviet space."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Vahe Demirjian", "view_list": [18, 17, 5, 90]}, "920": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 6, "name_list": ["Malcolm Kogut", "John Bruss", "Diane Harder", "Jake Guthmiller", "David LaDeau", "Peggy Krise"], "question_title": "Why do we worship with music?", "topic_list": ["Religious Worship", "Worship and Worshipping", "Music", "Religion"], "no_of_view": "1,309", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["People go to church to be healed. Nope, won\u2019t work\u2026\nNow what? OK, yer common pedal power, or \u201cwall wart\u201d, is nine volts DC, maybe around 150 milliamps (ma) in current, and with a \u201cmini-plug\u201d on its cord end, with one of the two patterns that Matt\u2019s shown. This data is usually on the label on the back.\nIf you get the manufacturer\u2019s original power supply for that pedal, \u2018done deal. Or, you can buy a generic supply with a set of adapters - if the specs are OK.\nOr you can take a scrounged (otherwise appropriate spec\u2019d) \u2018supply and change out the mini-plug end, with a repair plug, wired to swap the polarity. A little stripping & soldering, per Youtube. Sooner or later, many electric players will learn this practical skill\u2026\nThe thirty bucks or so it takes for tools is covered by the first time you don\u2019t need a pro shop\u2026 Like for a popped wire to your guitar\u2019s output jack, or a wire loose from a control pot, or improving shielding inside the control cavity, or changing out a broken end on an instrument cable, etc. But I digress.\nBut if you gather six pedals, ya end up with six power supplies, a mess of cables, and a need to get a \u201cpower strip\u201d (or two) to plug them all into. And few who play electrics with a pedal ever stop at just one\u2026 So, back to the store\u2026\nSomewhere around three pedals, look at multi-pedal power supplies. Some pedal makers market these, but, again, the polarity may not match what you need. But, since 9V/150ma DC is the same no matter which brand, we\u2019re just back to cables. Per the above.\nPersonally, I used a multi-outlet for many years, with a batch of self-made cables to supply a half-dozen different makes of pedals. Original single wall-warts, if any, got tossed in a box. Still kept a couple of lithium 9V\u2019s with me on the road, just in case (and for my sweet tuner).\nYou too can do it. Inhale enough solder and life gets simple.", "No it will not. I\u2019m not 100%!sure, but it\u2019s possible that you could damage your pedal by trying. Just buy the correct power supply, or use a battery. Here is one of my pedals, it works with a standard power supply. If yours doesn\u2019t look like this, I would look up the pedal on the manufacturers website and see what power supply they recommend.", "No, absolutely not. This is one of the best ways to turn your nice guitar pedal into an expensive paperweight.\nBecause most effects pedals operate off of DC current rather than AC, it is very important to use the correct power supply with the recommended specifications. This is typically labeled either on the bottom of the unit, or next to the power supply connector, or both.\nUsing the incorrect power supply can easily result in some nice sparks and smoke if the components are pushed past their tolerances, which will be much more expensive to repair. If in doubt, contact the manufacturer, and they will be happy to suggest the correct power supply for your use.", "Dude, Music is so much more than this. Please get a fucking clue", "You mean a positive centre adapter instead of a negative centre one?\nNo.\nNot only no, but I can't guarantee your pedals' safety if you try.\nYou must always match the polarity and voltage specified on the pedal, and use a power supply rated at a high enough amperage (usually measured in milliamps or mA) to match or exceed the requirement on the pedal. Give a pedal more voltage than it's designed for and you might blow it up. Give it too little and it won't work properly (analogue pedals sometimes don't work properly in interesting ways\u2026).\nAmperage is the only one that doesn't need an exact match- the pedal won't draw any more current than it needs, so as long as your power supply is rated for at least the same amount of milliamps the pedal needs (but ideally quite a bit more) it'll work fine.\nIt's well worth investing in a dedicated audio power supply, if only because it'll be less likely to introduce noise in to your signal. Something like the Truetone One Spot is relatively cheap but effective. Get it as a bundle with a daisy chain cable and some adapters for different DC jacks and you'll be all set.", "Probably not, though I once plugged a Line six AC power supply into a Roland keyboard (that needs a DC supply) and it worked (must\u2019ve rectified it its self!)\nIf you\u2019re not using the \u201cwrong\u201d power supply for anything, you could cut the cord and re-solder with the polarity reversed."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Alex Andrisca", "view_list": [47, 59, 46, 5, 88, 74]}, "291": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Albana Prishtina"], "question_title": "Do you think we albanians have good music?", "topic_list": ["Albanian Ethnicity and People", "Albania", "Music", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "747", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Why not.\nWhile i\u2019m sad that some Albanian songs that, according to me, are beautiful, like this one\ndon\u2019t have the attention of many Albanians, i like also some of those songs that have million of views and are considered hits.\nAnd, it isn't true that only Kosovo produce those songs.There are many songs from Albania that are hits in the Albanian world. Wave has the following basic properties: wavelength (frequency) and amplitude. In terms of sound, these translate into pitch and loudness.\nSound is a wave in a medium (air, water\u2026) Based on the medium, it will propagate at different speed and also be damped by different rates.\nWaves generally bounce and refract from/at obstacles. The position, shape and material of these obstacles has impact on how much and how.\nWaves combine with other waves. How depends on their wavelength, phase and amplitude.\n(And it\u2019s quite likely that I forgot some effects that may affect sound in real-life conditions.)\nAll the above are effects we can experience in real life\u2014these are not just some \u201ctheoretical\u201d effects. Pitch and loudness are clear, sounds sound differently in air and under water in a swimming pool, differently in open space and in a cave, and any musician will tell you that to record a song well, you need properly equipped studio (with walls that absorb sound). Or, ask a shooter whether it\u2019s more comfortable to shoot out in the open or in a tunnel range\u2026\nAn interesting real-life example: I buy my groceries in a supermarket where the cashiers beep when the lady reads the bar code\u2026 You know what I mean. I never go to one of the cashiers\u2014a specific one which has the beeper positioned just so that where I stand while bagging my stuff, I\u2019m directly at the point where I receive the beep at incredibly annoyingly high amplitude. When I move just a little (but inconveniently), the sound gets much more bearable. I can only conclude that this is some sort of inconvenient spot where the waves recombine after they bounced, producing much higher amplitude that makes my ears ring\u2026"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Bhavin Patel", "view_list": [850]}, "428": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What is the best song by PrettyMUCH?", "topic_list": ["Mankirt Aulakh (Punjabi Musical Artist)", "Song Lists", "Songs Recommendations", "Song Lyrics", "Rock Music", "Song Identification", "Music Recommendations", "Musicians", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "282", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Ayush Das", "view_list": []}, "965": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["Michael Fleischmann", "Anonymous", "Roger Hughes", "Neil Anderson"], "question_title": "Why does it seem like the artists that have died young make the best music? If someone was a mediocre artist with the potential to become a great one, but died before that could happen\u2026 you haven't heard of them. If they're briefly great but would have churned out pap for the rest of their careers had they not ODed or driven into a bridge abutment, you both hear of them and never get put off by their later rubbish.", "Well, of course we\u2019ll never know if Jimi, Amy, Kurt, and others were going to go and make even greater music, or if they\u2019d hit their peak and would be spending the rest of their careers churning out substandard albums, and dozens of lame covers.\nThere is certainly an idea that musicians create their best music when they're younger, which is not necessarily the case with painters, or playwrights. I think part of this is the image of the tortured young quixotic artist, fighting the system, is more saleable than the established and rich one remembering their past. There are certainly more issues with being young and poor than being old and successful.\nThere is a certain amount of confirmation bias within this. It\u2019s possible to say that great rock and pop music is made by younger artists, but the industry promotes those artists. Also, historically, artists released far more material in the past when albums made up most of the revenue, and tours promoted album sales. These days the opposite is true, so far less music is released. The Beatles released 12 studio albums in under 7 years. Ed Sheeran has released 4 albums in 8 years.\nCertainly there is a quality in the material of people who are young and hungry that is lacking once an artists is an established one. The idea of writing songs about missing your \u2018baby\u2019, or struggling to pay the rent if you're a 60 year old rock star in one of your mansions on your 4th marriage is a little hypocritical.\nBut that does ignore the great music produced by older artists, writing interesting and age appropriate songs. There was some criticism of Kate Bush when she did her one set of live gigs in 2014, and based these on her later works. She came to stage dressed as a 56 year old woman, and sang songs that worked in her established eccentric catalogue; the idea that she may have come on wearing stockings and singing Babooshka is ludicrous, and would be like Mick Jagger complaining he can\u2019t get no satisfaction, or Roger Daltrey stating he hopes he dies before he gets old.\nThere are artists who older singing songs that fit their current image, and much of it is great. Bowie\u2019s last two albums deal with ageing and dying; Springsteen still manages to write about the issues he sees in modern USA. There are others still making great music, that isn\u2019t being promoted, but is interesting and thought provoking. "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Writing music in general, regardless of genre, is very difficult. Even being a songbird and playing four chords is very difficult. Obviously, it\u2019s not mechanically difficult to do this sort of music, but it is very difficult to make a good song.\nCompare that to EDM, which, even \u201ceasy\u201d genres like house are usually 24+ tracks. Something like trance, hardcore, and dubstep are often 75 to 100+ tracks.\nThe big challenge of EDM is that it isn\u2019t just about tossing notes on a midi with a Kontact library. It\u2019s about using samples, synths, and effects to create a soundscape, and even at 8 tracks, this isn\u2019t easy to do at all.\nOn top of learning synths, plugins, and a bit of music theory, to create EDM, you have to know your DAW and how to get those sounds. You also have to have an eye and ear for constantly mixing as you go along. You can look at the 1,000 questions posted a day in Quora and various forums to figure out how difficult and mind-bending mixing in itself is.\nIMO, making EDM is extremely difficult, but so isn\u2019t making music if any form.", "Aside from the question as to what exactly you mean by EDM\u2014which is a stupidly wide umbrella that honestly is completely useless a term, for the most part\u2014the answer to the question as to how easy or hard it is to make is pretty stupid as well:\nAs easy or hard as it happens to be for you, and/or as you make it for yourself. Corporate music DID exist in the 20th century, but now any idiot can throw a four-measure ostinato together (they call them \u201cbeats\u201d), yell some quickly delivered rhymes without much social value, and make a hit record. I was shocked when I heard Billy Joel use the \u201cF\u201d word in a song (\u201cLaura\u201d, from The Nylon Curtain <1982>). Now I am shocked when someone DOES NOT use the \u201cF\u201d word. I\u2019m not a prude by any stretch, but there must be a better way to mass-express yourself.\nLike I said - there IS some good music being made now, but you have to hunt for it.\nSorry if this offends anyone, just being honest. We are all partial to the music we grew up with - my grandfather was a saint to me, but I am sure that he hated the music I listened to when I was a kid. But comparatively, I think he would have liked my music better, after having heard a lot of the music that is being made today. We will never know. If they were not, then who wrote them?", "topic_list": ["Verses", "Verse", "Churches", "Christianity", "Music"], "no_of_view": "1,996", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [2, 1], "ans_list": ["Why do church hymnals only have four verses to Amazing Grace when there are actually seven verses? Were the other three verses written by John Newton? If they were not, then who wrote them?\nI have a copy of John Newton\u2019s autobiography which prints Newton\u2019s original hymn. There are six verses. I grew up with the four-verse version, but the fourth verse of that (\u201cWhen we\u2019ve been there ten thousand years\u2026\u201d) wasn\u2019t by Newton. FWIW the hymnal we use (Common Praise) prints six verses -= the same as in Newton\u2019s autobiog, and doesn\u2019t include \u201cWhen we\u2019ve been there\u201d.\nFWIW the Newton\u2019s verses were:\nAmazing grace\u2026\n\u2019twas grace that taught my heart\u2026\nThrough many dangers\u2026\nThe Lord has promised\u2026\nYes, when this heart and flesh shall fail\u2026\nThe earth shall soon dissolve\u2026", "Generally, hymnal publishers don't print all the stanzas of a hymn because some congregation participants see many stanzas and refuse to sing, they get weary. So printers print only a few stanzas.\nBTW the musical word is stanzas of a hymn . Verses are in poetry."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "James Smith", "view_list": [70, 50]}, "970": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Brian T.s.", "Koibito Takingz"], "question_title": "What are the ideal songs for Jojo's Bizarre Adventure?", "topic_list": ["JoJo's Bizarre Adventure", "Anime and Manga", "Music Recommendations", "Manga", "Anime", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "547", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["You\u2019d be surprised how well Roundabout by Yes fits in with JoJo part 1 and 2. This is something that makes an earbud more durable\nso they last longer.\nTo fix this problem, open up the muted channel with the help of required tools and see if the joint needs soldering. There would be 3 trumpets, including a specialist lead player who didn\u2019t normally take solos, 2 trombones , 3 or 4 saxes doubling clarinets, piano, rhythm guitar, bass and drums. Most bands would also carry a vocalist, usually female, or two ( male and female.) Some, such as Tommy Dorsey and Glenn Miller would have a vocal quartet. Artie Shaw at one period also had a string section."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Efrayim Bulka", "view_list": [30]}, "996": {"no_of_follower": 4, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Reba McLane", "Dannika Esquibel"], "question_title": "Why do some ARMYs/non-fans have a problem with BTS having a \u201cwestern\u201d touch in their music? I will give you 6 reasons for this .\nLack of musical knowledge\nIt also depends on how much 'western' music the person has listened to\nThis is a simple notion that I have observed - sometimes people are caught up in the feeling of nostalgia that whenever change is presented to them , they feel contempt towards it .\nSome people don't bother to listen to the artist and would rather project their wants / tastes on the music the artist makes .\nHerd mentality.\nMost important reason. Some international fans think that kpop revolves around them .\nSo if I have to talk about the first point . I will give an example .\nMap of the soul 7 : ON . This song uses the korean traditional musical scale ( except jk's bridge) . Now , a person with not sufficient knowledge about music making will not notice this .\nOr\nBlack Swan . This one uses an asian string instrument . Still I have seen people call it plain trap song .\nOr the ultimate example\nIdol. He was writer known for his cartoons, songs, and children's His books have been translated into more than 30 languages and have sold more than 20 million copies as well as Golden Globe Awards and Academy Award nominations, he was the recipient of two Grammy Awards. His musical output included a large catalog of songs; a number of which were hits for other artists, most notably the rock group Dr. Hook & The Medicine Show including \"The Cover of 'Rolling Stone'\", \"Freakin' at the Freakers' Ball,\" \"Sylvia's Mother\", and the cautionary song/tale about venereal disease, \"Don't Give a Dose to the One You Love Most\".\nHe was the author of Tompall Glaser's highest-charting solo single, \"Put Another Log on the Fire\"and Johnny Cash's \"25 Minutes to Go\", about a man on Death Row with each line counting down one minute closer and also wrote one Cash's best known hits, \"A Boy Named Sue\" as well as \"The Unicorn\" recorded by The Irish Rovers. You have to count and pay attention there are rests and you have to listen carefully to the cues. I recently did just that. Years ago I played the string bass in high school and college orchestra but haven't t played in an orchestra for several years. I am an alumni of New England Conservatory in Boston. I am a Classical Guitarist. Because of the current coronovirus situation the graduation ceremony at New England Conservatory was cancelled. To lift the graduates spirits they are putting together a virtual orchestra where everyone records their part at home. They sent me the entire orchestral score although I played \u201c Pomp.and Circumstance\u201d many times in high school and college orchestra s, I never heard the beginning fanfare section we never played that part in high school. They also sent me a click track( metronome) and a click track with first violin. There were three free measures at the beginning where I was to start recording and count out loud. I actually did not start playing my part until two minutes into the piece I had to count measures and it was helpful to listen to the violin part in my headphones so it would not bleed into my recording. It was a fun project and I am anxious to hear the final result next month. The bottom line is you have to read along with the music and count accurately so you come in at precisely the correct place .", "Are you being serious? They read it the same way you're reading this. Only music notation rather than words.", "The individual parts are on the music sheetS for each musician to play together.", "Well musicians train to read sheet music since they start playing their instrument and technically the director is not indispensable. Sheet music contains 90% of the information needed to play a piece, including of course indications for when to play. You just need to count the bars in your head and play when the score tells you to.\nOf course when playing in bigger ensembles the director becomes a crucial element because it is easy to lose track of time and tempo when so many things are happening.\nThe director usually raises his left hand on the beat before the entrance of an instrument and points towards the specific player, just in case they forget their entrance (usually after many bars of silence).\nHope that clarifies things for you.", "Q.When a music director gives a music notation sheet, to each of the instrument players before a song recording, how do each musician understand that notation and also know when he has to play during the course of the song?\nA.The director will use a standard notation that is known by all the players. Generally, this notation will include \u201crests\u201d that tell the players when not to play, as well as \u201cnotes\u201d that tell them what to play in the appropriate places.", "How does each musician understand the notation? They know how to read music! If the various instrumental parts are fully written out, they are able to sight-read their part and play it at the correct speed (tempo) with little or no practice.\nHow do they know when to play and when not to play during the song? That\u2019s also written in the sheet music, using musical symbols called \u201crests\u201d, which tell the musician for example, \u201c\u201cdon\u2019t play for [x] number of beats (or measures), then begin playing here.\u201d"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Vaani Shree", "view_list": [85, 3, 1, 67, 73, 64]}, "109": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What are the best romantic songs from the 80s? Top line is for cymbals and hi hat, middle line is for the snare and bottom line is for the bass drum, explaining as simple as I can in layman\u2019s terms. The song is in 4/4 time.", "Usually like music for tuned instruments, but:\nThere\u2019s no key signature. There\u2019s also often no clef.\nDifferent notes/positions on the staff represent different instruments:\nUsually the snare drum is written on what would be the \u201cC\u201d position on a treble-clef part.\nBass drum is usually written on what would be the lower \u201cF\u201d position on a treble-clef part.\nCymbals played with the hand are usually written above the staff\nHi-hat foot notes are usually written below the staff\nToms are usually written everywhere else.\nIf it\u2019s for just one percussion instrument, there may only be one line on the staff.\nMore often than not, cymbals are written with crosses rather than regular notes. I prefer otherwise, personally.\nWhat looks like a trill to other musicians is a roll to a drum player.\nResonant instruments such as cymbals often have an open-ended slur starting at the note: This indicates the cymbal should be allowed to vibrate.\nDrum kit parts usually allow for some freedom of expression: A good drummer will rarely play exactly what the dots say - unless it\u2019s a very technical part.\nThere\u2019s all too little standardisation. Any or all of the above may be ignored or unknown to any particular composer or arranger."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Jose Abarca", "view_list": [281, 25]}, "347": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["David Clickner"], "question_title": "So on Spotify there are those videos that appear when you are listening to the song. They come in a variety of shapes from a fully round hoop to doubly curved. Some have a skin / membrane/ drum-head stretched over one side of the hoop. In all cases there will be sets of jingly bits (zills) or bells. However there are models that are considered tunable due to the head / membrane being attached to the hoop with a tuning system to tighten it up or down when and as desired, same as any drum on your drum kit."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Jose Abarca", "view_list": [17]}, "101": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "If you were to throw an OLD SCHOOL party right after the coronavirus madness is over to celebrate happily, what are at least 6 songs from the 80's that you would like to see your friends and everyone else invited jamming and dancing off of?", "topic_list": ["1980s Music", "Dance Music", "1980s", "Parties and Partying", "Music Recommendations", "COVID-19 (2019-2020)", "Friendship", "Hypothetical Scenarios", "Music", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "246", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Ralph Hemphill", "view_list": []}, "49": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Kwon Kicker", "Chhavi Porwal"], "question_title": "Where do I learn dancing in this lockdown?", "topic_list": ["Learn to Dance", "Hip Hop Dance", "Dance (performing art)", "Dance Music", "Lockdowns", "Social Dance", "Dance (activity)", "Learning New Things", "Learning", "Music"], "no_of_view": "501", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["You can learn it from you tube", "You can learn through youtube as many choreographer has started their YouTube channel and make the easy going step to learn. "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Bhavin Patel", "view_list": []}, "440": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Chand K Sharma", "Jimmy Durchslag"], "question_title": "Who has gotten the distinction of being the first music director in films?", "topic_list": ["Music Directors", "Movie Directing", "Movie Soundtracks", "Movie Directors", "Music Industry", "Movie Business and Industry", "Musicians", "Music", "Movies"], "no_of_view": "424", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["In silent era of films there were no music directors. A local person would stand in front of the viewers and explain the story and actions of the scene. To keep people occupied some local instrumental players of Harmonium, Sarangi, Sitar, Flute or some other Indian instruments would play some music. It is interesting to know that Ace Maestro Naushad started his innings at Lucknow with this type of bands under Ustad Babban Khan and Yusuf Ali Khan. This practice later paid him high dividends that he emerged as most authentic background music composer.\nWhen sound was added later from film Alam Ara even then there were no music directors. The hub of film industry was at Calcutta, New Theaters. harmonium players were called \u201cPeti Masters\u201d who set some songs to tune and rhythm and some British of German would assign instruments. Background music was done by the foreigners.\nRC Boral, Shyam Sunder, Puknaj Mullick and Anil Biswas were the early batch of Music directors but they did not have any status. Even their credits appeared in chorus and no special slide was used for them. There were no playbacks also. Songs were recorded on actor singers during the shooting in one take after making several rehearsals. The music scene was dominated by Rabindra Sangeet and later some Muslim music directors added Punjabi lure when production started in Bombay and Lahore. Ustad jhande Khan, Ghulam Haider, Mushtaq Ahemd etc were the prominent music directors.\nIt was Anil Biswas who first grasped the nuances of Western music in films like harmony, counter melody, and other styles. A hit film of that era was Kismat that ran for three years with success.\nNaushad joined the scene. He accepts the contribution of Anil Biswas in training and helping in in early stage as his mentor. There was mono recordings on one track. The Cutler Feeder microphone required to be heated for some time before it could pick up. Naushad brought Hindustani music ( the folk music of Uttar Pradesh). His film Rattan was a super hit. The entire cost of the film was Rs 75000 but it earned royalty of music only for Rs, 3,50000. There was no looking back for Naushad and rested of the developments and styles he gets the credit> At the age of 21 years he earned a \u2018Star status\u2019 of being the only music director in Film industry whose name was enough to sell the film all over India. With him the music directore started getting individual credit in films titles and certain other improvements were ushered in the status of singers, musicians and the like. This is just an bird\u2019s eye view of the development.\nChand K Sharma", "I would go with Alan Crosland who directed The Jazz Singer with Al Jolson, the first feature length film with an audio track as part of the film. There were other films with separate synchronized music before then.\nAlthough not until 1933, a lot of credit should go to Busby Berkeley for advancing movie musicals through outrageous choreography, innovative camera shots and incredible sets. In that case, the guitar will lock out of tune, and you won\u2019t be able to even five-string your way through the set. Replace the broken string as soon as possible (you do carry a spare set of strings, don\u2019t you?). As soon as you can, replace the whole set of strings, as the new one will be brighter-sounding than the others, and if you\u2019ve broken one already, chances are that another will follow shortly. Changing the whole set before one breaks is a good idea\u2014when the wound strings get thumpy instead of clear-sounding, it\u2019s time to change your strings.", "You replace it", "The obvious answer is that you change it. It is one of the first things you should learn as a guitar player, changing strings. How you change strings depends on the guitar type and there are tons of YouTube videos detailing how it is done on all sorts of guitars.\nIt is also recommended that you keep an extra set, plus extra strings on the ones that most often breaks. On steel string and electric guitars, that will be the plain ones. On acoustic nylon strings, the wound ones (basses) are usually the ones to go first.\nNow, if you break strings on stage, you have to keep playing or change guitar. You really need to be a heck of an entertainer and storyteller if you can manage to keep the attention of the audience while you change a string!\nIf you have an experienced band with you, they will continue while you change guitar (please tell me you have a back-up ready to go..).\nIf it\u2019s an acoustic or an electric guitar without a floating vibrato system. you just keep playing - the guitar don\u2019t go out of tune. If you have a floating vibrato system on your electric guitar, almost all of them will make the guitar go wildly out of tune and you have to swap out the guitar.\nIf there is something missing, something else you might want explained, feel free to give a comment.", "You take the broken string off and replace it with a new one of the same kind and gauge.\nHowever, if the strings on your guitar have not been changed for a long time and are old and dull sounding, the new replacement string is going to sound very different (bright, crisp, louder) compared to the others, in which case you should replace all of the strings.", "You can order single strings\nonline\nat\nJust Strings", "You replace it.\nThe thiner higher pitch strings tend to break more often.\nYou can also just replace them when you feel the start sounding dull, or start getting harder to tune, or don\u2019t stay in tune.", "Keep playing if you\u2019re in the middle of a song.\nI was doing a week long gig in Timmins, Ontario. Temperatures were in the -50s most of the week and we had to walk to the gig with our instruments. Must have had some effect because, for the first time in my professional life, I broke a bass string. The \u201cA\u201d string to be exact. This was the day before New Year\u2019s Eve and no stores were open to get a replacement.\nI moved the G & D strings up one and played New Year\u2019s on a three string bass.\nI miss those times. \ud83d\ude0e", "Replace it. with another string.", "If the rest of the strings on the guitar are getting old, replace them all with a new set. Pitch intervals are composed of notes that vibrate at specific frequencies. Because notes vibrate in the medium of transmission, usually air, they can interact. That interaction is called consonant or dissonant depending on how much of the energy of the two \u201cparent\u201d vibrations goes into the \u201coffspring\u201d vibration. The less energy, the more consonant; the more energy the more dissonant. As each pitch interval of any chord produces this third \u201coffspring\u201d vibration (except the tonic - octave interval which produces no third vibration at all and is perfectly consonant) they all interact. The multiple interactions are what produce a set of vibrations which can be judged consonant or dissonant.\nThere are two aspects to consonance and dissonance; objective and subjective. The objective aspect is that every pitch interval produces a definite amount of dissonance, from zero (tonic - octave or Do-Do) to a lot (staying with the western equal temperament scale of 12 semitones) that would be the tonic - augmented 4th interval, sometimes referred to as the tritone. This phenomenon can be seen as a graphic display on an oscilloscope and has nothing to do with whether a given person enjoys or is repulsed by a given chord.\nThe subjective aspect is what a person likes when it comes to consonance and dissonance. When I was young, I delighted in consonant intervals and detested dissonance; now I prefer a judicious blend of both as relentless consonance is boring and relentless dissonance is irritating.", "Unresolved tension between two or more pitches in the chord. This is a result of two or more tones that are a half or whole step apart, or that are the inversion of those intervals, major and minor sevenths. Any diminished or augmented intervals within a chord also causes dissonance.", "Anything that doesn\u2019t belong to the harmonic series", "It\u2019s rather subjective -\nthat being said, it really comes down to intervals. Some intervals play well together and some don\u2019t. (Almost literally based on how often their waves crest and trough together, this is called interference and may be worth checking out).\nFor example: A perfect 5th is consonant and when played with a root makes a nice consonant chord. If you use a tritone with the root it\u2019s by and large more dissonant.\nSo one thing to consider are the intervals involved. Now what makes it a bit more complicated is when you add more and more intervals to your chord\u2026\nYou have to consider their distance from the root, AND their distance from one another.\nFor example, half steps are often considered more dissonant. You could play an \u2018A minor 7 9 chord\u2019 with this voicing : A B C E G this will be a crunchier voicing than spacing the B and C further apart. A C E G B\nNow we have nice spaced out thirds from one another instead of a half step (or minor 2nd)between the B and the C. This may sound better or not to people, but the literal interference between the half step is audible, especially in lower ranges.\nThis is one example of how the perceived dissonance of a chord is affected by all intervals involved.\nTldr: If you\u2019re a beginner, here\u2019s my list of scary intervals: minor 2nd, tritone, minor 6th. Make a chord and put a bunch of these intervals in it. It will be dissonant (to most people) Also I should add that context helps as well, a passing diminished chord probably sounds wayyy sweeter than a 32bar diminished chord ; )", "Not an easy thing to answer. It\u2019s really cultural. In western music assonance is based upon the basic triad although people are now accepting of more complex chords. There are those who will give you mathematical explainations but on the whole it\u2019s a matter of what sounds good to YOUR ear. Music of other cultures will often sound very strange to us but containing great sensitivity and emotion to those of that tradition..", "When \u201cout of chord\u201d ,out of harmony-as humanity has so fallen!"], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Jonathan Polina", "view_list": [7, 33, 10, 1, 33, 17, 1]}, "443": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Tony Bruno", "Susanne Dodson Anderson"], "question_title": "Who is playing the piano in the soundtrack of \"The Nanny\" TV serie?", "topic_list": ["Playing Piano", "Soundtracks", "Learning Piano", "Learning to Play Musical Instruments", "Television", "Television Series", "Music"], "no_of_view": "260", "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Mistah Sheffield?", "Marvin Hamlisch"], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"], "question_author": "Bernard Geyer", "view_list": [2, 5]}, "210": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Teddy Stern"], "question_title": "My dream is to own a Rickenbacker 325 (58 or 64), but they are too much money for me. Does anyone know why they are so expensive?", "topic_list": ["Electric Guitars", "Guitarists", "Guitars", "Music", "Personal Question"], "no_of_view": "734", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["This will be a rather poor answer, but no matter- I\u2019m tired!\nRickenbacker made very few guitars. Like, very, very few. In 1958, Rickenbacker made ~28 325s. I couldn't even find data for the other years; that\u2019s how uncommon they are. For reference, in 1958, Gibson shipped about 434 Les Pauls in the same year. From 1958\u20131960, Gibson also made 1,300 335s. (I couldn\u2019t find an exact figure for 1958, but you can infer that it might be a little bit more than a third, at somewhere around 450 perhaps.) So yeah- Rickenbackers from that era aren\u2019t going to spring up for sale every day. Owing to the most basic laws of economics, this also means that they will be more expensive when they do.\nNevertheless, best of luck to you, and if it\u2019s any consolation I\u2019ll point out that there are plenty of relatively normal people out there who own vintage Rickenbackers. Even if you can\u2019t find a \u201958 325, the little secret I\u2019ll share with you is that pretty much every single old Rick\u2019 is going to share at least some portion of that classic tone- certainly enough to set it apart from any other brand of guitar. And, if that\u2019s still not good enough, I\u2019ll say that a lot of the reissues are lovely guitars as well. Just don\u2019t get me started on their new Fireglo finish!"], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Alex Andrisca", "view_list": [208]}, "824": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Jon Teske"], "question_title": "How come instrumental child prodigies are usually on piano or violin?", "topic_list": ["Child Prodigies", "Prodigies", "Learning Violin", "Violins", "Learning Piano", "Pianos", "Learning to Play Musical Instruments", "Musical Instruments", "Children", "Music"], "no_of_view": "679", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["A four or five year old is physically able to play piano if the repertory is carefully selected for their hand size, and if the instrument is scaled down, a violin, viola, or cello can be played. Wind and brass instruments cannot be scaled down, their range is a function of their physical size. There are no mini-bassoons, your arms have to be of a certain length to reach the lower keys of clarinets, oboes or flutes. One has to be a certain size to play any member of the sax family. A small child does not have the lung capacity to blow any blowing instruments for a sustained period. This is why wind and brass instruments are usually introduced in later grade school. A scaled down violin, viola or cello won\u2019t sound like a Stradivari, but they can be played. Why is this so?", "topic_list": ["Singing", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "337", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["You got a problem. Try simple melodies first. Play 4 bars and try to sing it or play it on the piano. Then do another 4 bars. Repeat it over and over, just 8 bars. Wait 2 hours. Then try to play it again. If you can play chords, make sure you play the chords with the melody. That helps. Then, next morning when you get up, try to play or sing the melody. If you have it, go on with the next 8 bars. An additive process.\nOnce you memorize some melodies, it becomes easier to do. But keep reviewing all the melodies you have memorized."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Anonymous", "view_list": [30]}, "504": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["John Mcgarry"], "question_title": "What are some gospel musician secrets?", "topic_list": ["Gospel Music", "Music Industry", "Musicians", "Music"], "no_of_view": "708", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["The Love of God\u2026 and soul"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Jonathan Polina", "view_list": [6]}, "383": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What will be the benefits of playing devotional songs and music several times in a day? When you breathe in do you tense your stomach muscles and try to push them out?\nWhen you breathe in allow your tummy to expand naturally and in a relaxed way. Breathe as though your lungs are in your tummy. That\u2019s exactly whet it feels like.\nas you breathe out try and create the support for each note you sing in this way The higher the note the lower the base of support- The lower the note the higher the support. Or put it another way when you sing low relax more, when you sing high tense muscles lower and lower in your torso.And each note requires a tiny almost imperceptibly different amount of air pressure or air speed . But don\u2019t worry or think about this - it happens naturally if you let the body do it and don\u2019t think about it or try to achieve it in a conscious way.\npractice support by lying down and breathing in, relax and notice your tummy go up. Do not tense but at the end of the in breath try to get your tummy muscles to gently and gradually push the air out.", "Try this\u2026\u2026hold the palm of your hand on your stomach and when you sing, push against your stomach and force the air through. After awhile you will pull your diaphragm up without thinking about it. A way to practice is to force your diaphragm up when you talk normally Awkward for about a week if you're working it. If it sounds like your normal conversation seems a bit forced, keep doing it After a short time, it will be a part of your normal breathing. As a player he is definitely distinctive and springs from a solid range of classic influences himself; I am not seeing Frusciante being revered in the same way that Johnny Marr is for example, but he has a solid following, and a devoted number of modern guitar players who extend respect.\nThe origins of what we recognise as being the \u2018Pantheon\u2019 is obscured by today\u2019s highly \u2018boutique\u2019 music culture, we no longer have a monolithic range of \u2018chart toppers\u2019, rather we now have a vast spread of music bloggers, and independent music projects which have no overarching commercial relationship, as in the Classic Rock era, we don\u2019t have radio networks calling the shots, nor do we have a central \u2018mainstream\u2019 music establishment any longer.\nI think Frusciante is a highly regarded player, a unique exponent of modern rock in fact, however I don\u2019t think we have the same music industry anymore, definitely a niche following."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Ryder Pittz", "view_list": [1, 86]}, "104": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Phil Jones (He / Him)", "Ronald Pelletier"], "question_title": "How much money do artists make from Spotify and Apple Music?", "topic_list": ["Apple Music (product)", "Streaming Music", "Social and Online Music", "Spotify (product)", "Artists and Creative Professions", "Music Industry", "Musicians", "Apple Products and Services", "Music", "Money"], "no_of_view": "423", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["How long is a piece of string?\nI\u2019ve made about 9 cents on Spotify since I started putting my music there last year. Minute doses of a drug are just taken out by the Liver and do not enter the bloodstream. Of course, there may be a placebo effect. How can I check if it's original or not?", "topic_list": ["Stradivari", "Violinists", "Learning Violin", "Violins", "Musical Instruments", "Music", "Personal Question"], "no_of_view": "634", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["It is estimated that Stradivari produced 1,116 instruments, 960 of which were violins. Around 650 instruments survived, including 512 violins.\nAll of Stradivari\u2019s surviving violins are believed to be accounted for, and their past history and present ownership is known to the violin world\u2019s leading dealers and experts.\nIs it possible that your instrument is a long-lost, previously unknown genuine Stradivarius? Sure, there\u2019s probably a .0001% chance of that, but there\u2019s a 99.9999% likelihood that what you have is a copy of a Stradivarius.\nAntonio Stradivari was recognized and acclaimed as a master luthier within his own lifetime, and many, many other violin builders, over the last nearly 300 years, have modeled instruments after his, using his design and specifications to construct their own violins. Then they put a Stradivarius label inside \u2014 not because they\u2019re trying to fool anybody into thinking it\u2019s a genuine Strad \u2014 but simply to let buyers know that the violin is a Strad copy, as opposed to being a copy of some other famous maker\u2019s violins, like Maggini, or Stainer, or Guarnerius.\nNow that you know that your violin is not a genuine Stradivarius, but a copy, you might still want to know who actually made it, how old it actually is, and how much it might be worth. In that case, you\u2019ll need to take it to a violin dealer who can examine it and give you an expert appraisal. Unlike guitars, where the maker\u2019s name is almost always clearly labeled and there\u2019s usually a serial number to help determine date of manufacture, many violins are not so labeled and there\u2019s no easy way for a layperson to determine the maker and age.", "Sorry, you don't have a Strad.\nStradivarius made around 1,100 instruments. About 650 survive today. They are all known to one degree or another. The likelihood of you finding an undiscovered Strad in a storage unit/grandma's attic/pawn shop is less than you getting stuck by lightning when you go to pick up your lottery jackpot winnings and then getting eaten by a shark.\nJust about every violin made has a famous makers name inside. Stradivarius being the most famous, the majority of instruments over the last 250 years have probably been made in his pattern. Guarneri, Stainer, and Amati are common names/patterns. It isn't/wasn't to deceive but to indicate the model.\nJust because it isn't a Strad doesn't mean it is worthless. Even mass produced violins from the 19th century can easily be worth over a thousand dollars, depending on quality and condition. On the other hand it may be another run of the mill student instrument with a retail price of $300 USD.\nThe only way to be sure is to take it to an expert to get an idea of what you have. An eyeball estimate is usually free. A detailed written estimate starts around $50 USD."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Zakwan Nasser", "view_list": [73, 176]}, "642": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Lewie Docksey", "Chris Mccarron", "Simon Peake"], "question_title": "Who is a singer or a band considered a classic in your country that people should know?", "topic_list": ["Classics", "Country Music", "Bands (music)", "Singers", "Rock Music", "Singing", "Music Industry", "Musicians", "Countries of the World", "Music"], "no_of_view": "540", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Split sofa find them on any download site u will be thanking me soon\ud83d\udc4d", "The late Stomping Tom Connors. The movie was a fictionalized version of director Cameron Crowe\u2019s real experiences in the Seventies. When Crowe was a teenager, he was already writing columns and reviews for music magazines, and got to go on tour with several major rock bands. He met and befriended a lot of real musicians and a lot of real groupies.\nMost of the things that happen in the movie are based on real events. Crowe really saw King Crimson\u2019s manager trade a groupie for a case of beer. He really saw a stoned Robert Plant proclaiming \u201cI am a golden god\u201d to fans. He really did get abandoned in an airport by Lynyrd Skynyrd (and then ran into his sister, a real-life stewardess, who got him home!). Crowe\u2019s mother really was a neurotic professor.\nBut Crowe chose to blur the lines between reality and fantasy in the movie. He created the fictional character William Miller to represent himself. He created Penny Lane as a cmposite of Bebe Buell and several other groupies he met on concert tours. And he created the fictional band Stillwater so he could pretend that all his anecdotes happened to one band on one tour.\nSOME of the characters in the movie were real people. Lester Bangs was a real music critic who helped young Cameron get into journalism. Ben Fong-Torres was a real editor who published some of Crowe\u2019s articles in Rolling Stone magazine.", "(Taken from a previous answer of mine on almost the same subject)\nWhile there was an actual band named Stillwater playing southern rock out of Georgia during the 1970s, they were not one of the bands the Almost Famous Stillwater was based on. Before filming began on the movie, the director had to clear the name Stillwater for use in the film from the band members. Upon receiving and reading the script, they agreed to let the movie use the name."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Cozma Dan Claudiu", "view_list": [2, 87, 65]}, "658": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Stephen Lory", "Phillip Milner", "Stephen Wildman"], "question_title": "Is Studio One the best DAW?", "topic_list": ["Music Production Software and Apps", "Digital Audio Workstations", "Music Production", "Music"], "no_of_view": "259", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["It is one of them. ABBA: The Album was the highest-charting album of the group's career, peaking at No. 14. Five albums received RIAA gold certification (more than 500,000 copies sold), while three acquired platinum status (selling more than one million copies). The compilation album ABBA Gold: Greatest Hits topped the Billboard Top Pop Catalog Albums chart in August 2008 (15 years after it was first released in the US in 1993), becoming the group's first number-one album ever on any of the Billboard album charts. It has sold 6 million copies there.\nThe Beatles on the other hand have sold 600 million records. They have received seven Grammy Awards, four Brit Awards, an Academy Award (for Best Original Song Score for the 1970 film Let It Be) and fifteen Ivor Novello Awards.\nTime Magazine named them among the 20th century's 100 most important people.\nOne last criteria: What do Quorans think of the two bands?\nThe relative numbers tell the story. [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Bhavin Patel", "view_list": []}, "546": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["Alan Wilson", "Ronald J Brown", "Ryan Shaffer", "Michael Mays"], "question_title": "When the Messiah comes, will God reveal an 8th musical note?", "topic_list": ["Musical Notes", "The Messiah", "Music Theory", "God", "Music", "Religion"], "no_of_view": "818", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 2], "ans_list": ["Maybe but he could blow up whatever we got too!", "When the Messiah comes, will God reveal an 8th musical note?\nWhat on earth are you talking about? There are already 12 pitches in common Western usage and some cultures use even more pitches. Jazz has notes that do not occur in the classic scales. So, there is no need for a magic creature who lives in the sky to reveal an eighth note because we already have more than that available in our music. Very strange question.", "The idea of seven musical notes in a scale is not God-ordained\u2026at least any more than other ideas for scales.\nThe diatonic scale was originally an ancient Greek concept, having been restricted to \u201cGreek modes\u201d from the 4th century \u0299.\u1d04.\u1d07. to the Middle Ages.\nThe majority of early believers in Christ were considered Grecian, from the perspective of the Roman empire. So was the culture of the eastern half of that empire, which contained the province of Judea, as well as most of the other areas mentioned in the New Testament as having been missioned to.\nWith the proliferation of the Orthodox and Catholic Churches, then, came the proliferation of the diatonic scale in some form. The missions that proliferated them were usually sponsored by one monarchy or another: the Byzantine Empire for Orthodox missions; various western post-Roman kingdoms for Catholic ones. Just like their claimed predecessors, the Romans, these monarchies took to a colonialist attitude of belitting other societies and their cultures as necessarily primitive.\nIn other words, the diatonic scale\u2019s popularity is a product of power, not of any divine mandate.\nHonestly, the Lord loves whatever we have to give Him\u2014of whatever aesthetics\u2014just as long as we offer it with a pure and pretenseless heart.\nA fun fact, however, is said that most cultures actually conceive of the pentatonic scale first. This is the same scale as ancient Rome was using all that time: their uses always approximating C,D,F,G,A.\nIt could also be argued that without first knowing the pentatonic scale\u2019s F-C-G-D-A order of fifths, the Greeks would never have reached the diatonic\u2019s F-C-G-D-A-E-B.\nAdditionally, the chromatic scale (upon which all of traditional Western music has been based) has twelve notes. That is setting aside things like quarter-tones, as used in either of the two classical music traditions of the Indian subcontinent; and overtones, which for the most part defy twelve-tone equal temperament.", "This is a very interesting question! So let\u2019s start by talking about what we do know:\nThere are already scales with more than 7 notes. The reason we stick to diatonic scales are because they are directly derived from the physics of sound, and they are the first (and, hence, most prominent) tones generated in the mathematics of acoustics. Also, the human ear innately hears these tones before all other \u201cless obvious\u201d possible pitches. But there are plenty of scales that either \u201cremodel\u201d the intervals of pitches from the 12 chromatic notes we commonly have at our disposal (for instance, the octatonic scale\nis a derived scale that alternates whole and half steps; depending on how you start the alternation, it can actually be used to make some pretty cool tonal jazz settings), or rely on actual frequency modification for \u201cnotes,\u201d as in microtonal music. So finding an \u201c8th musical note\u201d is not hard\u2014depending on how you want to count it, it\u2019s been done already.\nThe Bible does not make a practice of discussing music theory. While there\u2019s some supposition that the \u201cselah\u201d in the book of Psalms gives guidance to performance practice (and this is largely conjecture), there\u2019s never any language about music from a structural standpoint such that an introduction of a \u201cnew note\u201d would have any meaning or value; it would be so far out of context for eschatological doctrine as to be more of a distraction than anything useful for spiritual growth (which is really the point of such texts\u2014to encourage right living now in view of what\u2019s to come).\nNow to the meat of your question (and considering your specific use of the word \u201cMessiah\u201d), I have to ask: what\u2019s youre perspective? I\u2019m a Christian, so my opinion is based on the notion that this is not Messiah\u2019s first visit to our little third rock from the sun. (Of course, I\u2019m not a Mormon, so I don\u2019t believe he\u2019s been back to visit the Native Americans, but that\u2019s an entirely other matter.) However, if you\u2019re Jewish, Yeshuah isn\u2019t really a \u201cthing\u201d for you and you\u2019re still waiting on the actual Messiah\u2026 except Jewish theology has long eschewed treating Isaiah and other Messianic texts as prophetic of an actual Messiah, choosing rather to interpret them as prophecies for the Jewish people, so \u201cMessiah watching\u201d probably isn\u2019t your speed. (If that\u2019s you, we\u2019ll just have to agree to disagree.)\nI\u2019m going to proceed from the assumption that you\u2019re asking after the Christian doctrine of \u201cthe second coming of Christ.\u201d\nThe New Testament states that the redeemed of the Lord will be \u201ccaught up\u2026 in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air\u201d (1 Thessalonians 4:17\n). At this point, there\u2019s some debate about where we go and when this happens, but Scriptures indicate that when this happens, we receive new bodies (1 Corinthians 15:51\u201353\n). What most theologians believe is that this does not speak of a new \u201cmode of existence\u201d that is fundamentally different than we have now\u2014that is, we will receive new physical bodies\u2014but will no longer have a sin nature. There are two important considerations that, in the context of this question, create bit of a tension with regard to certainties and possibilities as pertains to your question:\nWe will have physical bodies: that is to say, we won\u2019t be ephemeral \u201cghosts\u201d that have been \u201cabsorbed\u201d into some \u201cconsciousness that we call \u2018God\u2019\u201d or some whack New Age weirdness like that. This means there\u2019s no supposition that the laws of physics as we know them will suddenly stop (as the bodies we\u2019re in now, and presumably the ones we\u2019ll receive, were made for this physical universe as it is, only without the taint of sin.\nWe will be utterly perfect: this is more vague, because the Bible is (probably intentionally) silent on what exactly \u201cimperishable\u201d means beyond the obvious matter of \u201cno death or decay.\u201d\nWill we all be one race? Probably not; in Revelation 14:6\n, John saw \u201can angel flying directly overhead, with an eternal gospel to proclaim to those who dwell on earth, to every nation and tribe and language and people,\u201d and this is after Messiah has already physically appeared and is on the ground on Mt. Zion.\nWill we be genderless, or will there still be men and women? Jesus told the Sadducees in Matthew 22:30\n, \u201c[In] the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in heaven.\u201d And we know less about angel physiology!\nWill we have babies? There is far less evidence for this than against it: babies are a byproduct of marital love (which will be nullified, per the above point), but this speaks more about the deeper spiritual desire we will have for Jesus than any physical or emotional desire we will have for another person that there would be some urge to procreate.\nHere\u2019s the tension, especially with regards to music: while we will have physical bodies, we know that they will be superior to the bodies we have now. Could this include an ability to hear sounds in a physically perfect world that would organize in some kind of octatonic scale with modified frequencies that sound utterly foreign to us now, but will make sense \u201cwhen this corruptible puts on incorruptible\u201d? Maybe, but I doubt it.\nI think music has its emotional gravity\u2014its ability to penetrate and manipulate us and bypass the thought process with almost utter disregard\u2014because its very physics communicate to us that there is another plane of enjoying God\u2019s creation that our bodies just can\u2019t access yet. It\u2019s not like all music is perfect (believe me, you can launch Spotify and catch Miley Cyrus or Katy Perry and hear how simultaneously so beautifully close and horribly far we are in music composition and performance styles to music that is remotely perfect or in any way transcendent), but I do think the ability to quantify\u2014or even qualify\u2014music in scientific terms is elusive because it\u2019s not made to be understood by a fallen mind. As long as we have sin, we can recognize something that is sublime, but will never\u2014in these bodies such as they are\u2014be able to comprehend or fully appreciate it. We have trouble enough coming to a consensus on how to understand and discern good music now, so I\u2019m disinclined to think there\u2019s necessarily something wrong with the physics of music such that it needs an overhaul. It\u2019s our hearts, minds, and ears that need to be fixed!\nAll that is to say this: I don\u2019t think music needs a renovation, by adding another pitch or whatever. I think our understanding of the universe as God intended it will be complete, not that a new law of physics will necessarily come into play. But hey, that\u2019s just my thinking. I haven\u2019t been there yet, so it\u2019s not like I\u2019m talking from experience; these are just my musings and are not more or less valuable that anyone else\u2019s.\nLet me just quote Paul from 1 Corinthians 13:12\non this: \u201cNow I know in part; then I shall know fully, even as I have been fully known.\u201d"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Kevin James Durain", "view_list": [2, 16, 18, 30]}, "351": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Jax Maximus"], "question_title": "What is the mechanism in a music box called?", "topic_list": ["Music Boxes", "Mechanisms", "Music"], "no_of_view": "282", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["The ratchet lever [1] rotates the cylinder [2], the pins pluck the comb teeth [3] which produces the music. And use a very simple rhythm. In country and bluegrass music we start with a boom-chick strum where you pick the bass note on the chord then strum the top three strings. That can work or anything else very simple.\nMost people try to start with complicated shuffle patterns that have lots of up and down strokes at full speed. Of course they crash.\nUse a metronome set to 60 beats to start and just try to match the beats using all down strokes.\nStrum lightly. Most people dig in too deep. The pick should just dance atop the strings. You should be able to use a heavy pick without it being pulled out of your hands or breaking. If it grabs you are strumming too deeply. If you have to use an extremely flimsy pick to keep from dropping it you are strumming too deeply.\nIt may help to just practice right hand with the strings muffled instead of trying to chord till you get the first part right.\nStart slow with simple all down stroke strums using a metronome. Do it for 10 or 15 minutes every day. Gradually increase speed and add more complicated strums. Everyday practice is important. 15 minutes per day every day is better than 10 hours on Saturday and six on Sunday with nothing between. It is a physical skill and takes regular practice.\nMost people starting guitar focus on the left hand. The right (strumming and picking) hand is more important and needs attention.", "Oh boy.\nRhythm is one of those things in music that some people seem to have a natural talent for, and others take a while to get the hang of.\nI think I had an okay feel for rhythm starting out; I started beatboxing and with guitar I never really had a problem with strumming patterns.\nOn the other hand, It took me hours at a drumkit before I could play anything resembling a backbeat, and I've seen other beginners pick it up in a tenth of that time.\nSo focus on rhythm. How much listening to music do you do? How much listening to music with drums, do you do?\nTry dancing, table drumming, snapping your fingers to music, beatboxing, or something else more intrinsically a rhythmical pursuit than guitar.\nBasically, it will come with practice. Sooner than later with practice specifically geared towards improving rhythm.", "The easy answer is practice. But you need a direction to follow. Or you will just play the same forever. A metronome can be helpful and also be a serious pain. The simplest way, honestly, is to tap your toes as you are playing. That will help you keep in rhythm."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Henry Locke", "view_list": [30, 19, 37]}, "574": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Eoin Carney", "Connie Casella", "Sam Campbell"], "question_title": "What song did Paul McCartney write for John Lennon?", "topic_list": ["Paul McCartney", "John Lennon", "The Beatles (band)", "Musicians", "Songs", "Music"], "no_of_view": "1,462", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 3, 0], "ans_list": ["Pipes of Peace", "Paul wrote, \u201cHere Today\u201d for John Lennon after Lennon was murdered and released in 1982 on Paul\u2019s album, Tug of War. For a dance band or many stage bands, No. However; for an orchestra or most \u201cformal\u201d music groups, usually you would need to read the drum part. This is much different than reading say, piano music with scales and cords. Drum music is often on one line and has more than timing, such as \u201cflam, long roll, five stroke roll, etc. I have worked with both types of groups and each has it\u2019s own advantage.", "Most players don't, some do. There are lots of different levels of reading ability. I can read drum notation but not to a high enough standard to play a chart I have never seen before. If parts are complex it would take me a longer time to figure out from reading music than just hearing the music generally.
