Janowiak", "Ed Wool", "Sam Utz"], "question_title": "How do I easily change guitar strings with a Bigsby on the guitar?", "topic_list": ["Guitar Strings", "Acoustic Guitars", "Electric Guitars", "Guitarists", "Playing Guitar", "Guitars", "Musical Instruments", "Music"], "no_of_view": "1,033", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 4, 0, 2], "ans_list": ["You don\u2019t.. Really, you don\u2019t. Now I\u2019m sure there are some of you folk out there that love Bigsby\u2019s, but I\u2019m not one of them. They are archaic, poor attempts (along with the Fender) at a new device that performed poorly at best. I have never seen one that would come back in tune after using the bar. And for many years, it stayed that way until Floyd Rose came along and made the only system that works and increases your sustain. Kayler\u2019s don\u2019t hold a match to the Rose, period.", "The previous answer is correct", "Get a Vibramate Spoiler, a slotted string anchor that fits onto the string pins on the Bigsby. It\u2019s held in place by string tension, and is much easier to deal with than trying to keep the strings\u2019 ball ends from popping off the pins. Otherwise, a stock Bigsby is a royal pain to restring.", "Your problem is that you are asking for the condition easily. As bad as some folks make it sound, it is just fussy because Bigsby uses those silly little pins onto which you must slip the ball end of the string. If they only had drilled chamfered holes into the roller rod (like many Bigsby clones & knockoffs did even way back in the 1960s) most of the hassle would be gone.\nAs it is, the \u201ctrick\u201d is pre-bending The string right behind the ball (where the string core is wrapped around itself) such that when you slip the hole in the ball end over the pin, it naturally wants to curve around the roller bar wher you cann catch it and put tension on it so it doesn\u2019t fall off the pin. That little trick alone can save you many headaches when you are in a hurry. Some players keep a mini needle-nosed pliers in their case for just this purpose. [Add 10 bonus points if you buy a quality small (not mini) needle-nosed pliers with a hardened steel cutter notch at the back of the jaws for clipping your strings after installation.]\nA second \u201ctrick\u201d is to use a dab of petroleum jelly on the ball end to temporarily stick the ball to the pin with a bit of goo. This will keep the ball on the pin long enough the thread the string around the roller, grab the free end, and pull to keep it under tension. If in conjunction with pre-bending The string, you\u2019ll rarely drop the end of the string off the pin and have to re-finesse it onto the pin. The petroleum jelly thing doesn\u2019t work when it\u2019s very warm, like in the middle of summer, unless you smear it on like butter\u2026but don\u2019t do that, please. You\u2019d regret the mess.\nAnother Quoran has suggested an aftermarket solution and I know the Vibra-mate product just works. It makes changing strings as easy as Bigsby should have made it decades ago when they were working out the initial bugs in their vibrato tailpiece systems. Dang it, Paul (Bigsby), couldn\u2019t you have just drilled that roller bar?!", "One string at a time\u2026 that has always worked for me.", "Well, there is the three hand method, where you get a third person to hold the string on the pins!\nBut seriously, there are actually two products you can get to make it easier.\nOne is the Callaham String Shaft\n. It allows you to string the strings through the shaft instead of on the tiny pins.\nAnother is the Vibramate String Spoiler\n. Same idea, except you don\u2019t have to remove the old String Shaft.\nI have no affiiliation with either company and have used both products successfully, although I just do it the old fashioned way Typically mixing involves:\nGain staging - Making sure every vocal and most instruments have the same consistent volume throughout the whole song via gain automation.\nCompression - Correcting any volume inconsistencies that made it through your gain staging.\nEqualization - Removing or lowering specific frequencies that are too loud/bright(piercing)/muddy(ugly), or to just make room for other frequencies.\nSaturation - Essentially stretches out the frequency range for a specific sound, making it sound louder when it\u2019s really just more present.\nLimiting - It\u2019s basically a compressor that works way harder, used when you want to heavily balance a sound at the expense of dynamics(e.g. loud sounds and quiet sounds have the same volume, where as with a compressor, loud sounds and quiet sounds will be closer to each other, but you can still hear the volume differences). Many hip-hop producers only use a limiter on the master track when mastering or on heavy kicks and 808s.\nPitch Correction(Auto-Tune and Melodyne) - This one is a bit different than the others as it is more of a flavor effect than a \u201ctrack balancer.\u201d It\u2019s mostly used on vocals but can also be used to tune certain instruments, especially 808s.\nDe-esser - If you\u2019ve ever recorded you might have noticed that your T\u2019s and S\u2019s have a bright, piercing sound that most other letters do not have. You need a De-esser to reduce these piercing sounds, but not too reduced, otherwise you will sound like you have a lisp. You can also EQ out sibilance by hand if you do not have a de-esser, but I highly recommend one.\nNoise Gate - Gets rid of any sound below a certain threshold. If you have a fan going on in the background for example, it will cut off the fan and leave your voice. It only works to an extent though, as it will often only cut off parts when you\u2019re not talking. It can also be used on instruments.\nDelay - You could refer to a delay as an \u201cecho\u201d because that is what it is most of the time. It essentially just gives your vocals or instruments an echo effect or a doubling effect with no need to record additional lines.\nReverb - If you\u2019ve ever been in a church and noticed the echo when somebody is singing, that is reverb. It\u2019s not just any echo however, but an echo simulated according to the size of a room. The smaller the room, the shorter and less present the echo is.\nSo those are most of the terms used when referring to mixing. As for the actual mixing process, experiment! There are some general rules to follow when mixing, but there is not a formula to follow to give you the best mix for every single song. ALWAYS do pitch correction first, then your next two should always be either a compressor first, eq second, or eq first, compressor second. They both sound better or worse depending on your song, so try both or see which sounds better and stick with it! After these you have a lot more freedom to do what you like and it will be different for you, but for me, I like to use a de-esser afterwards, a multiband compressor such as soundgoodizer, OTT, or a manual one such as FabFilter\u2019s. After that I use saturation to make it a little louder. Noise gate afterwards, especially if you\u2019re a home studio artist, then last but not least, flavor effects such as delay and reverb(if you use both, make sure they don\u2019t collide too heavily). If you\u2019re a novice don\u2019t worry too much about additive and subtractive eq, but once you\u2019ve mastered everything else, i\u2019d recommend learning about them.\nIf you need to learn how to use these techniques, youtube is a good place to start and too complicated to type into a quora post. There are people who literally spend decades learning these techniques and are still learning new things.\nOn to mastering. Phew. You got past the hardest part, mixing! Mastering is in a nutshell just raising the volume of your track. Typically it only consists of limiting, glue compression(only sometimes!), and sometimes eq. For the sake of this post, limiting is the one that does 70% of the work. If you\u2019ve done a good job mixing, mastering should be a piece of cake(in theory, but it is actually more complex than mixing) and if you struggle with it too hard, it\u2019s because your mix is not good enough."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Ali Abouei", "view_list": [16]}, "425": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Ayush N", "Jake Arnott"], "question_title": "Is it possible to play music from a USB stick in a USB port in a car?", "topic_list": ["USB Ports", "Car Audio", "USB Powered Devices", "Flash Drives", "Universal Serial Bus (USB)", "Computer Hardware", "Computers", "Technology", "Music", "Cars and Automobiles"], "no_of_view": "183", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["yes u can, thats why its there", "You can in my car (a Nissan Qashqai - but the audio system is German). What did he want to say when he wrote Run to the Hills?", "topic_list": ["Ironmaiden", "Rock (Black Lagoon character)", "Purpose (2015 album)", "Heavy Metal (music)", "Music", "Interpersonal Interaction", "Life Advice"], "no_of_view": "96", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["That deep in his heart he knows that you are a homosexual"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Maria Thompson", "view_list": [1]}, "720": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["Joseph Baldassarre", "Ralph Pearce", "David Boyles", "David Smith"], "question_title": "Why do we use a musical scale that doesn't allow BC & EF to have halfsteps?", "topic_list": ["Musical Scales", "Musical Notes", "Sound Engineering", "Electronic Music", "Music Theory", "Music Composition", "Classical Music", "Sound", "Musical Instruments", "Music"], "no_of_view": "852", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 1], "ans_list": ["B to C and E To F are half-steps. Our system of scales evolved over hundreds of years and were set sometime before 500 BCE.", "C major does it", "The \u201cwhole step\u201d \u201chalf step\u201d terminology is an historical artifact related to thinking about scales using piano keys. So, in modern Western music these days, we have a equal temperament, chromatic scale that consists of 12 intervals (e.g. starting on C and thinking in sharps, not flats): C, C#, D, D#, E, F, F#, G, G#, A, A#, B, C\nThe reason why there is no half step between E&F or B& C is that the list of intervals above is already in equal steps. So to go from C to C#, you multiply the frequency of C by 1.0595 (approximately, there are many more digits to get it exactly), then to get C# to D, multiply the C# frequency by 1.0595, and so on until you reach C up an octave which is a frequency of twice the lower C.\nSo, the frequency difference of every note in the chromatic in sequential order is 1.0595 that of the next lower note. Thus, the actual frequency difference in percent between E and F is the same as between F and F#, or D# and E. Same goes for B to C. the difference is the same as between C and C#, or A# and B.\nIf you were to add another note between E and F or B and C, it wouldn\u2019t fit in any common Western scale.", "You are talking about the whole-tone scale that starts on C. It goes C-D-E-F#-G#-A#-C. It was a device developed in the late 19th century, specifically with Impressionist music from France, but you also find pieces of it within serial music of Germany. If you are familiar with impressionistic paintings, you\u2019ll know that pastel colors were often used, and figures appeared less distinct, giving an \u201cimpression\u201d of them rather than a stark and accurate representation. In music, this scale, along with the chromatic, octatonic, and pentatonic scale, were utilized to mask the idea of a central tonality. Certainly it is a C scale, but it\u2019s not major, nor minor, nor does it fit any of the modal scales from the late medieval and renaissance periods. Nowadays the whole-tone scale is used in film to accompany dream sequences or flashbacks."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Shane Davis", "view_list": [19, 26, 108, 138]}, "47": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What are some light folk music?", "topic_list": ["Traditional Music", "Folk Music", "Music"], "no_of_view": "327", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Korey Daniel", "view_list": []}, "100": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What is America's music?", "topic_list": ["Music", "The United States of America"], "no_of_view": "192", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Korey Daniel", "view_list": []}, "541": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["John Fleming", "Irina Nenartovich"], "question_title": "How do I increase the tempo on 3:4 polyrhythm pieces in piano?", "topic_list": ["Tempo", "Fr\u00e9d\u00e9ric Chopin (composer)", "Piano Performance", "Playing Piano", "Piano Music", "Learning Piano", "Pianos", "Learning to Play Musical Instruments", "Classical Music", "Musical Instruments", "Music"], "no_of_view": "425", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 1], "ans_list": ["As in Chopin\u2019s Fantaisie Impromptu (6:8 or 3:4 if you prefer), the key is to develop independence between the left and right hands. Slow practice until you no longer think note for note. Then gradually increase the tempo. It works. For some, poly-rhythms are easy. For others, it takes a little longer. I learned my independence using my hands and patting the rhythms on a table. It\u2019s a little like rubbing your stomach and patting your head or vice versa. Try it, you\u2019ll like it.", "If you can play slowly correctly this group, then start to go over whole musical phrase. Think by larger patterns. Try not to stop and not to dig on the pattern, but try swim ming over."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Andrew Vincent", "view_list": [32, 29]}, "635": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Luke Hellwyck", "Rhys Gethin", "Cameron Smith"], "question_title": "Who is Austin Boath?", "topic_list": ["Fame and Mass Popularity", "Celebrities", "YouTube", "Music"], "no_of_view": "669", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["Fucked if I know.", "Austin Boath(born 25th November 2005) is an Australian young Entrepreneur, writer and musician", "Austin Boath is a young entrepreneur, he sings in the band Paint The Town Brown & he has a YouTube channel called Scxlly. Over the past few months his presence has been growing fast online.\nTrivia: He has a cat named Marvin & a Porsche 911 Carerra in his garage!"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Mettaton Undertale", "view_list": [56, 106, 206]}, "297": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 7, "name_list": ["Thomas Dalton", "Wayne Hajas", "Bryan Foreman", "Noah Kaufman", "Paul Woo", "David Levy", "Conrad Gachne"], "question_title": "Why is there no B Sharp?", "topic_list": ["Music Theory", "Music"], "no_of_view": "4,202", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 1, 1, 1, 0, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["It is just a consequence of how we've decided to name the notes. Notes are named based on a particular minor scale. We call the tonic (first note) of that scale A and then name the rest of the notes in the scale in ascending order. A minor scale only contains seven out of the twelve notes in the chromatic scale, so we go back and fill in the other five in the appropriate gaps, calling them sharps and flats. The note a semitone above B is in the A minor scale, so it is called C and there is no missing note from the chromatic scale to squeeze in-between B and C.", "There is a B-sharp. It has the same pitch as C-natural.\nThere is only a semi-tone between B and C or between E and F. B-sharp is the same as C-natural. C-flat is the same as B-natural. E-sharp is the same F-natural. F-flat is the same as E-natural. If you look at a piano keyboard you will notice that there are some pairs of white-keys with no black-keys in between.\nFor the other notes, there is a whole tone difference. A-sharp is the same as B-flat and they are both half way between A and B.\nIf you remember the order of sharps in the key signature - Father Charles Goes Down And Ends Battle - B is the last note to get a sharp.\nFor people who understand chords better than I do, there can be good reasons to write a B-sharp instead of a C-natural. When I am reading music, B-sharps still freak me out a little and I wish they were written as C-naturals instead.", "Well this is an interesting question. Their is a Cb in the circle of fifths but no B#. So I googled a bit and found the following:\n\u201dThe B-sharp major scale has 2 sharps, 5 double-sharps.\nWarning: The B-sharp key is a theoreticalmajor scale key.\nThis means:\n> Its key signature would contain either double-sharps or double flats.\n> It is rarely used in practice, because it is too complex to use.\n> It is not on the Circle of fifths diagram\n, which contains the most commonly used keys.\u201d\nThis is an accurate quotation. I just assume it\u2019s true. The Harvard Concise Dictionary of Music is silent on the matter.", "The other answer is correct. However, just so you understand that there are a couple ways to think of pitches, you should know that it depends on the harmonic context. If you have a C# chord, B# would be the name of the natural seventh scale degree. You would have to call it B# to distinguish it from the root tone of the chord. Or if you had a G#7 chord, B# would be the major 3rd above the G# tonic since diatonic chords are spelled in 3rds (i.e., every other letter name in the scale). B is the 3rd of G, therefore B# is the 3rd of G#. If the G# chord is switched to Ab, you can go back to calling your B# a C.", "There is, but\u2019s it\u2019s the enharmonic equivalent of C. Same thing with E and F. If you ever look at a piano keyboard, you\u2019ll notice that there are no black keys between E-F and B-C.", "Same reason there is no E-sharp. A \u201csharp\u201d simply raises the pitch by a half-step. A half-step up from B is C. A half-step up from E is F. This really has nothing to do with which physical piano keys are white or black. The smallest interval in the diatonic scale in Western music is the half-step. So there is no place in the diatonic scale for another note between B and C.", "There is. But usually we call it C, since no one likes reading in C#.\nBefore the 12-tone chromatic scale was standardized there was another note between B and C, and one between E and F. Over time we got rid of them. But we kept the names."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Vita Lea", "view_list": [442, 336, 307, 402, 17, 470, 39]}, "78": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 6, "name_list": ["Hannah Frost", "Tony Baron", "Cristina Estepa", "Dennis Tucker", "Luke Hellwyck", "Peter Thorogood"], "question_title": "Hi everyone. "error", "topic_list": ["error"], "no_of_view": 0, "create_time": "", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "", "view_list": []}, "226": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 5, "name_list": ["Simon Kurpas", "Daniel Michalak", "David Mann", "James Miller", "Evan Landy"], "question_title": "Minor second, Major Seventh, same distance with the root but one is minor the other, major, why?", "topic_list": ["Musical Scales", "Harmony (music)", "Music Theory", "Music Composition", "Music"], "no_of_view": "751", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Minor Second implies a note a semitone above the root, a Major Seventh is 11 semitones above the root\u2026 So, no, they are not the same distance. What would be closer to what you are suggesting are the Major Seventh and the minor ninth\u201413 semitones above the root\u2014which actually are both a semitone away from the octave\u2026 in opposite directions.\nSo, assuming you mean those: why are they called different things if they boil down to the \u201csame\u201d interval\u2014that is, a semitone? Context\u2026 They are used very differently, and also, if you tune in anything other than 12 tone equal temperament they instantly stop being the \u201csame\u201d distance, at which point the whole question becomes moot.\nIn fact, most questions in music that ask why \u201cthe same\u201d note or \u201cthe same\u201d interval is called something different depending on context, are often easily answered with \u201cbecause 12TET\u201d.", "One way to think of this is that these two intervals are inversions of each other, and as such, are \u201copposites.\u201d There are actually four such \u201copposed\u201d minor-vs.-major pairs, each of which \u201cadds up to\u201d an octave:\nminor second / major seventh\nmajor second / minor seventh\nminor third / major sixth\nmajor third / minor sixth\nFor example, if your root is C, the interval from C to the B above is a \u201cmajor\u201d seventh because B is the seventh note of the C-major scale. The interval from C to D-natural is a major second for the same reason.\nBut the interval from C to D-flat is considered a \u201cminor\u201d second (even though it\u2019s not part of a C-minor scale) because it has been \u201clowered\u201d by a half-step (in the same way that lowering major thirds and sixths by a half-step will yield their minor equivalents).", "In the real world we have something called gravity. It means that for an ordinary observer standing on the ground there is a clear difference between up and down. Musical space is similarly biased. In the harmonic series, harmonics get closer together as you go up, never the other way around.\nin music theory we say that larger intervals are called major and smaller intervals are called minor. It doesn\u2019t always gaurantee the major interval will sound happier than the minor version, but that is how we name them.\nNow imagine you have two notes an octave apart. Lets say C4 and C5. Now you place a note B in between them but closer to the upper note. To be more specific this new note is a half step (or minor 2nd) below the upper note, and a major 7th above the lower note. It only stands to reason that because the outer distance of an octave is constant, making one of the intervals larger, i.e. major, would make the other interval smaller, i.e. minor.\nThe same is true for other intervals which are inversions of each other such as:\nMajor 2nd vs. Minor 7th\nMinor 3rd vs. Major 6th\nMajor 3rd vs Minor 6th\nThe only time this doesn\u2019t hold true is for perfect 4ths and 5ths. Perfect intervals retain their \u201cperfect\u201d quality when inverted.", "Ok, C to C#/-flat is a minor second. C to B above is a major 7th. If that is inverted it is a leading tone which is a minor second. It all depends on the context.", "There is no minor 2nd. A major 7 is the \u201cleading tone\u201d What you are referring to as the minor 2nd, is actually called the b9 (flat 9). It\u2019s not minor. Minor only implies the minor 3rd."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Voilier Bleu", "view_list": [14, 27, 35, 20, I like music but it seems like it's too easy to harm yourself.", "topic_list": ["Loud Noises", "Hearing", "Music"], "no_of_view": "903", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 0], "ans_list": ["It is, if you need to ask And you can easily loss your hearing.. Take care of it\u2026", "When playing music through loudspeakers, it is easier to notice if is too loud; if you don't hear any sounds from your environment this is a sign of a too high volume. The increasing use of headphones lacks this \u201cwarning\u201d: you don't hear anything else when playing your music at a moderate level already, and are not warned if your volume is ear damaging. Briefly, typically one would take every other note, e.g, 1-3-5 this is a triad), where 1, 3, and 5 represent the first, third, and fifth notes of the scale. Seventh chords are similar but extend to the seventh, i.e., 1\u20133\u20135\u20137. Since there are often (but not always) 7 tones in a scale, you can extend these further such as 1\u20133\u20135\u20137\u20139 where the \u201c9\u201d is actually the 2nd note of the scale (\u201c8\u201d is the octave). Common extensions are 9, 11, 13 (but may be \u201caltered\u201d as in b9, #9, b5, #5, #11, etc.)\nSo as an example, the C major scale consisting of C-D-E-F-G-A-B(-C) would yield triads C-E-G (C major), D-F-A (D minor), E-G-B (E minor), F-A-C (F major), G-B-D (G major, A-C-E (A minor), B-D-F (B diminished). Other scales (e.g., C harmonic minor, C melodic minor) will yield different chords. These are diatonic chord as they come from the scale. Note also that the examples are in \u201croot\u201d position. If we \u201cvoiced\u201d the notes of the C major (C-E-G) differently, say E-G-C, it\u2019s still a C major but we would call it an inversion.\nThere are also symmetric chords from scales which have a repeating sequence of intervals such as diminished that yield diminished chords.\nThe notes of a chord can also be \u201ctweaked\u201d which are called alterations.\nNoticed how we took every other note? Those are a \u201cthird\u201d interval between notes. We can takes scales in fourths, fifths, seconds, etc. which work the same way but yield sometimes dramatically different sounds. For example., C \u201cquartal\u201d is C-F-B-E-A-D-G since we take very third note (a fourth interval)\nThere are a lot of qualifications that I omitted but this is big picture."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Philip Longee", "view_list": [55]}, "417": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "How can I become a YouTuber and secretly be a musical artist? What is evident is his unerring instinct for choosing the right instrumental tone colour for the occasion, especially in his miniatures. For this one need only look at the various dances from The Nutcracker - the cor anglais and bass clarinet in the Arab dance, the piccolo and pizzicato strings in the Chinese dance, the 4-horn choir in the Waltz of the Flowers, and of course the celesta in The Sugar-Plum Fairy, for which the instrument might have been invented - again, don\u2019t forget the bass clarinet!\nFurthermore, whether or not it was due to Tchaik\u2019s deep inner torments, but he produced some of the most achingly expressive music heard in the 19th century. Nothing in Wagner, I believe, surpasses the infernal agonies of the overture Francesca da Rimini. (Check it out.)", "Tchaikovsky was one of the greatest melodists ever. His melodies are unsurpassed. The one thing he had problems with is form. He produced three of the greatest ballet scores in the western world. Several operas, which are with the exception of Eugene Onegin underrated outside Russia, six symphonies, three of which are firmly in the repertoire. The most performed festive overture in the 1812 overtures and a host of other well known works. His contributions to music are enormous. ["Robert Berger", "Hal Cooper"], "question_title": "What is the average salary for a symphony orchestra musician?", "topic_list": ["Symphonies", "Orchestral Music", "Classical Music", "Musicians", "Salaries and Wages", "Music"], "no_of_view": "987", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [3, 0], "ans_list": ["This depends on the orchestra . The major orchestras in big cities in the US , New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston, Cleveland, Los Angeles and others have the largest budgets, the longest seasons and the most concerts per year , so they pay the highest salaries . A starting pay for a musician is generally around $ 150,000 , but the principal chair musicians such as the concertmaster, who is the head of the first violin section, the principals in the viola, second violin, cell and bass sections earn even higher salaries, up to maybe $ 250,000 or more . The concertmaster, who is the key member of the entire section , gets the highest salary .\nThere are other positions in the strings, such as associate concertmaster, who sits next to the concertmaster, the two assistant principal first violins , plus associate and assistant positions .\nIt\u2019s the same with the woodwind and brass sections . The principals of each section, flutes, oboes, clarinets, bassoons, horns, trumpets , trombones are paid more . There is only one tuba, and this player gets a pretty high salary .\nSame with the principal persuasion player . The tympanist is pretty much one position, but one of the percussion section players is also the associate principle tympani .\nIn the smaller regional orchestras , with their shorter seasons and lower budgets , some of which play only sporadic concerts rather than a full season, salaries are not as high . In some of these , players do not receive a salary but are paid on what is called a \u201cper service \u201c basis . A service is a rehearsal or a performance . Not every musician is needed for every performance, for example the tuba player . Here musicians are paid a certain amount for every rehearsal or performance they play . If musician is not needed for a concert, he or she is not paid .", "Ten cents a show."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Efrayim Bulka", "view_list": [110, 8]}, "284": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Don Forge"], "question_title": "What's a song/movie/book that you skipped but later found out it was dope?", "topic_list": ["Book to Film Adaptations", "Movie Recommendations", "Songs", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Music", "Movies", "Experiences in Life", "Life and Living"], "no_of_view": "863", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["I didn\u2019t watch Inception until like a couple weeks ago, but like\u2026 if you haven\u2019t seen it you need to. But even he has fans.\nIf you want to play to a larger audience though you need to become more mainstream. There\u2019s nothing wrong with that either.\nI would say you could follow a more traditional electronic music theme, which has a build up, a drop, and a recurring melody. On the other hand you\u2019d be one of many if you do that.\nTo be truly original you\u2019d have to make something that is its own style. But one thing is true for humans: they don\u2019t like repetition in art, that is the downfall of any piece. So e.g. \u201ctwinkle twinkle little star\u201d is one string of a repeated simple tune. It works for little kids, but people who are a little older won\u2019t be playing it all day and still loving it.\nBut don\u2019t take this the wrong way, repetition in art is also essential! If you listen to Bach it is a amazing amalgamation of repetition. However there\u2019s always a little twist: the melody is reverse, enhanced, made longer, shorter, faster, slower, is intertwined with other compositions, etc. That\u2019s what makes it creative.\nSo repetition, yes, but make it sparse, or modify it constantly. Very well produced imo", "OK, I just took a quick listen to \u201cLost in Darkness.\u201d To my ear, it\u2019s just OK. You made some interesting choices for patches and beats, but it\u2019s way too repetitive and droning for my taste. I\u2019d think of it as basically a backing track for some kind of cool melody or maybe some vocals - even spoken word if the lyrics are cool. As it is, you seem to be being very overcautious. Trust yourself more and don\u2019t overthink things so much.\nBut there\u2019s something deeper here for us to discuss. You are using words like \u201cgood\u201d and \u201cbad\u201d and \u201cmistakes\u201d to describe your music. Good and bad are 100% subjective and personal, so any opinions using those terms are going to be worthless. I suggest that you NEVER alter your creations based solely on whether one person (or a few people) thinks it\u2019s \u201cgood.\u201d The ONLY question to be answered here is \u201cdoes this music express what is in your heart? Do you have something to say to the world, and does this piece go anywhere toward saying it?\u201d NOTHING else matters.\nAs for \u201cmistakes,\u201d I suggest you learn to embrace your mistakes. In any art form - music, painting, or whatever, your hand will eventually slip and you will play a note you hadn\u2019t intended. You have two choices. You can say \u201cUh-oh, that was WRONG.\u201d Or you can say \u201cHmmm\u2026 I hadn\u2019t thought of playing that note before. I wonder what happens if I play that note, say, three times in a row, followed by a small riff to loop it back into the main idea?\u201d So if you make a \u201cmistake,\u201d you repeat it, or maybe even add a couple more \u201cmistakes.\u201d If it creates a dissonance, you have created a bit of tension in your music. You can relieve this tension by resolving the \u201cwrong\u201d note back to the \u201cright notes\u201d and repeat your main theme. Then when the next verse cycles around, you can repeat this new phrase you just wrote that began as a mistake. This is called improvisation, or more aptly, composing.\nYour subconscious has ideas of its own, and making mistakes is often one way that these ideas get born. In many cases, the music that comes from this deepest part of you is most likely to touch other people emotionally and make the music more meaningful to them."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, ["Ukuleles", "Learning to Play Musical Instruments", "Musical Instruments", "Music"], "no_of_view": "838", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 0], "ans_list": ["I\u2019m not a native english speaker so I might get the terminology completely wrong. But ukulele is a chromatic instrument so it can play the notes of any key signature. It\u2019s not like harmonica which only has the notes for a certain scale. I don\u2019t think it\u2019s correct to say the ukulele would be tuned to any specific key but maybe someone will correct me if I\u2019m mistaken.\nBut ok, so how is it tuned. There are some variations but the standard tuning is gCEA. So the strings are g4-c4-e4-a4. Some tune the string closest to the player an octave lower so it would be g3 in that case and you can still use the same chord shapes. This is also called the C6 tuning since it makes up the chord C6 when you play all open strings at once.\nThere are several different tunings but this is the most common.", "Most ukuleles (soprano, concert, and tenor) are tuned in the Key of C (GCEA tuning). But these sizes can also sometimes be tuned in the Key of D (ADF#B tuning) and even less often in other alternative tunings."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Smith Gilliam", "view_list": [25, 8]}, "744": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Rick Kennedy"], "question_title": "Can you tune a music box?", "topic_list": ["Music Boxes", "Music"], "no_of_view": "140", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["In one direction\u2026. sharper"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Jose Abarca", "view_list": [3]}, "522": {"no_of_follower": 4, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Jang Ye Hun", "Hudaa Musa", "Jeslyn Ang"], "question_title": "If Jungkook left BTS for some reason, who would be the main vocalist?", "topic_list": ["Vocalists", "Jungkook (BTS Member)", "Celebrity and Music", "K-Pop Idols", "K-Pop Artists and Groups", "BTS (K-pop group)", "K-Pop", "Musicians", "Hypothetical Scenarios", "Music"], "no_of_view": "1,162", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [2, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["I think Jimin would be because he is the lead vocalist but not the main. A low voltage. The preamp gain will amplify the signal to \u201cline level\u201d. Which is adequate to drive the power amplifier. A preamp may also be used for intentional distortion, equalization and have ability to add effects via an effects loop.", "I pre-amp allows a bass player to create the sounds they want to hear from the bass before it goes into the amp.\nUsually, this will include using some compression, setting up the EQ and using the DI output to run into a mixer for live playing or studio recording.\nMost come with effects and bass players can choose to use some of the effects for different songs, or stick with a certain effect they feel suits the style of music they\u2019re playing,\nIt\u2019s amazing how much better a pre-amp can make a bass sound and the control it gives the bass player. At the end of the song, Alanis says life has a funny funny way of helping us out - in spite of all of the bad stuff that we have to go through. The bad stuff helps us get to where we are going, and that is ironic.\nA former child actress turned dance-pop diva, turned herself into leading vocalist of alternative rock in the late 90s\nAlanis Nadine Morissette was born in Ottawa, Canada, on June 1st 1974. Alanis' Greek name is a feminine version of her father's name,\nAlan. Her mother's name's Georgia and she has two brothers: Chad and Wade (Alanis' Twin). She learned to play the piano at age 6 and the guitar at age 21. In 1986 Alanis made a single called Fate Stay With Me (b-side: Find The Right Man). She recorded two albums as a dance-pop singer in Canada: Alanis (1991) and Now Is The Time (1992). At age 18, she moved to Toronto and worked with several musicians and songwriters, but the collaborations didn't work. In 1994, she finally found the right partner: producer and songwriter Glen Ballard, who had already worked with many artists, including Aretha Franklin Micheal Jackson and Barbara Streisand\nShe moved to LA at age 19. On June 13th 1995 \"Jagged Little Pill\" was released by Maverick Records owned by Madonna . Alanis had found an autobiographical, extremely personal way to write songs. JLP has sold about 30 million copies around the world, turning into the highest selling female album and the 3rd highest selling album of all times.\nAlanis Morissette spent well over a year touring and promoting her 1995 album Jagged Little pill, which burned her out physically and emotionally. For the next year and a half, she took a lot of time off to decompress and re-evaluate. \"Thank U\" is her reaction to the conflicted feelings she had after achieving success.\nDisillusionment, frailty and silence are among the things and feelings Morissette thanks in this song, but at the top of her list is India, where she spent time in 1997. The trip was enlightening and gave her some of the ideas for this song.\nThis was nominated for a Grammy for Best Female Pop Vocal from the album Supposed Infatuated Junkie , but lost to \"I Will Remember You\" by Sarah Machlain\nAlanis returned with the song Uninvited, for city of Angels (1998) soundtrack on March 31st 1998. All other guitars came from the modern Classical Guitar. The steel string acoustic guitar is an American invention By the American Luthier Christian Frederick Martin who was a German immigrant and he started the C.F. Martin company. Originally The Classical Guitar was strung with gut strings and then by accident The Dupont company discovered nylon and some fisherman started string the guitar with fishing line Thanks to him we have nylon guitar strings. The reason the steel string acoustic was invented was before amplification the nylon string guitar could not be heard when playing with other instruments. With the afvent of Jazz an instrument was needed that could be heard with the other instruments. Although it seems that steel string guitars are more popular than nylon string guitars that is only so in certain parts of the world. In Latin America and Spain nylon strings rule and I. the US and Europe it is steel strings.", "The acoustic is lost to antiquity but it likely wasn\u2019t invented, it likely evolved from other instruments. Even now, there are many types of guitars that vary from what we consider \u2018standard\u2019 - size, number of strings, tuning, all vary throughout the world\nThe electric pickup is generally credited to Adolf Rickenbacker ( of Rickenbacker guitar).. it was installed into a lap steel guitar, nicknamed \u2018the frying pan\u2019.\nI believe that Les Paul iscosidered to be the inventor of the electric guitar, by installing pickups onto what was essentially a board. Nicknamed \u2018the log\u2019, he cut a guitar in half, stuck the log inside, and glued it back together, creating the guitar that would eventually become the ES 335.\nLike Henry Ford and the automobile, Leo Fender did not invent the electric guitar, but he did develop manufacturing techniques that allowed them to be standardized and mass produced.", "Modern classical guitar was invented by Spanish luthier Antonio Torres Jurado in the middle of the 19th century.\nTorres pulled together design elements from other guitars of his era into the design that form the basic one that classical guitarists still use today. So the 650mm scale length (copied by Leo Fender for his Telecaster prototypes), fingerboard width, general body shape, and traditional 7 strut fan internal bracing sytem all come from Torres.\nHere\u2019s classical guitarist Brendan Acker playing a restored 19th century Torres guitar. Not sure you could even tell the difference between it and a contemporary classical just by looking at it:\nAcoustic guitar is a little harder to nail down, but I think Christian Frederick Martin is probably the best contender. Its unclear whether or not he personally invented the X bracing system that supports the top of most contemporary steel string acoustic guitars, but he certainly popularized it and widely expanded its use.", "Double chambered resonator bodies of string instruments came from Central Asia and became sophisticated instruments in Persia. Rajastani pilgrims migrating west passed through Persia on their way to Andalusia and made modifications to the Persian \u201ctar\u201d, a word which means \u201cstrings\u201d or, the instrument with strings, the condition of being with strings. It was called \u201cgitano tar\u201d then that word morphed into guitar. The Persian tar is covered with a membrane made of pericardium (heart sac from sheep, cow) and the migrants modified that by replacing the humidity sensitive membrane with a wood covering that was very thin and supported by bracing. The Persian tar has moveable frets, the guitar has fixed frets which eventually followed the tuning of the 12 semitone equal temperament scale so one can play any chord in any key and still sound more or less (not perfectly) in tune. Metal strings were replaced by gut strings, then nylon. Gut frets were replaced with nylon frets (wrapped around the neck) then metal frets embedded in the neck / fingerboard. Tapered tuning pegs were replaced with geared tuning pegs.", "I believe that these instruments evolved rather than invented by one person."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Posey Hamrick", "view_list": [68, 53, 64, 57, 6]}, "469": {"no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Mike Rouse", "Anonymous"], "question_title": "Which country artist made a mercy dash to Canada to play guitar for Johnny Cash when his guitarist fell ill?", "topic_list": ["Johnny Cash", "Country Singers and Musicians", "Country Music", "Guitarists", "Playing Guitar", "Guitars", "Musical Instruments", "Musicians", "Canada", "Music"], "no_of_view": "613", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["I was at that concert and could here his distinct style of playing before he was introduced. It has happened to me while I\u2019ve been recovering from some flu, it\u2019s funny, but it usually goes away as fast.", "Hi Ashley, as always I would have to listen to you to know for sure what is going on. but yes, a breathy voice is a common issue and there are many reasons that can be causing it.\nFirst of all, you are absolutely right on wanting to get rid of it. A breathy voice means that your voice is working in a way that is damaging it. When your voice is breathy, you have to increase your air pressure which leads to further damage, creating a cycle.\nThere are many reasons why this can happen. To name a few of them:\n-if you smoke, the membranes of your vocal cords will be damaged and unable to close properly, leading to escape of air.\n-If you are constantly dehydrated. For example, if you don\u2019t drink a lot of water but you drink lots of coffee or alcohol drinks.\n-If you yell a lot your voice gets tired and weak.\n-If you work in a call center and have to be all day talking on the phone.\nIn my experience, this is an issue that can be resolved completely, but it does require mindful practice and in most cases, also some habits have to change.\nGenerally, you have to learn to use your whole instrument properly, but if you want to do something right now, the best thing I can tell you is to check your air support.\nTo make it simple and straight forward: if when you sing you are pulling your belly in, you are not using your air support properly. The air pressure that you send to your vocal cords is going to be too high.\nMake sure that you are breathing properly for singing (using the diaphragm), and that when you sing, you are supporting the air. Letting the diaphragm come to its relaxed position slowly. This will give you a low-pressure airflow and you will be able to control the sound from your vocal cords.\nHOWEVER: have in mind that if you have been a smoker for a while, or if for any reason the membranes of your vocal cords are damaged, it is not going to be a quick fix. It can be restored but you will have to be willing to make some changes.\nIf you are interested, I have just released a free workbook that is designed to help you prepare your body for singing. They\u2019re active, and they take the main line outputs from my Focusrite Clarett 4Pre Thunderbolt audio interface. They have served me very well, and I\u2019m still getting very good feedback on mixes I have done on them. They suit the sort of small room I inevitably work in!\nI have been thinking that it might be time to investigate some new monitors, but last year I moved from the UK to New Zealand, which was quite an expensive business, and I had upgraded my interface and studio computer just before that, so it will depend on how much my online mixing business is earning before I invest in new ones! I haven\u2019t researched the market recently, so I don\u2019t know what\u2019s current, or what I can buy in NZ, come to that.", "I am no expert in monitors. I come from DIY - believe it or not I use a combination of 3 speaker/monitor (out of need) I use cheap thin no bass $5 pc speakers along with big 125 watt bass heavy old Fisher Rs and a car stereo. If the mix sounds good on all 3 systems - it is a decent mix. I still like the horrible Yamaha NS10s (and knock offs) (they do everything wrong in the right way) They magnify the flaws. And the same with my system. I would love to have a better \u2018monitoring room and speakers\u2019 but I don\u2019t - what I can tell you is the acoustics of the listening room is huge - especially when you have bass low frequency songs - a bad room can severely mess up you producing and mix IMO. This works for me, for now ~", "What is your favorite brand and model of studio monitors, and why?\nAfter a lot of research and trying a few models and brands, I decided on the Focal Solo6 BE.\nGiven my room size, I do not need bigger monitors, and they do go down to 40Hz, which is plenty deep for most use cases when making electronic music.\nI decided on these because for the very tight and fast bass response combined with the excellent performance of the Beryllium tweeter.\nThe tweeter can go down to 500hz, which allows a crossover frequency around 1000hz, much lower then most monitors this size. That means there is less of an issue with the frequencies where you usually expect a crossover dip, especially for vocals. But the tweeters also go up to 40kHz, way above what you need, which means you never run into the limitations of the tweeter ever.\nThey are driven by a 100W amp for the tweeter and 150W amp for the woofer (both AB class specially designed for this speaker) and deliver 109dB SPL, plenty for any room these are designed for.\nThe guy who sold them to me told me he prefers them to the Twins as he says they sound cleaner. I have not tried the Twins.\nIf I would ever need bigger speakers, I would probably look at the Trio6 or Trio11 also from Focal. They make incredible studio monitors.\nThese are not exactly cheap. If these are out of your budget, make sure to try the Focal Alpha range that is much more affordable but still performs very good."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Sophia Rose", "view_list": [255, 306, 250]}, "435": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What was the largest interval Cole Porter could stretch on the piano? Some people claim that John Lennon\u2019s song \u201cCome Together\u201d was too similar melodically with Chuck Berry\u2019s song, \u201cYou Can\u2019t Catch Me\u201d. That\u2019s insane! The two melodies are distinctly different and the fifth to fourth to base chord progression is used in thousands of songs. The fact is, the owners of the song (and it wasn\u2019t Berry at that time) sued Lennon over the lifted words. Paul asked John about the lyrics, asking him, \u201cThat\u2019s a bit of a nick, isn\u2019t it?\u201d meaning, John copied the words directly. The different contexts of the two songs make the meaning of those words totally different. John replied to Paul, \u201cNo, it\u2019s a tribute.\u201d John lost that lawsuit and, as I recall, covered a couple of Chuck\u2019s songs as payment. The owners of those songs then received royalties when Lennon\u2019s albums were purchased. All in all, it wasn\u2019t too painful for Lennon, but he could have avoided the entire thing by changing those words just a bit\u2026 \u201cThere goes a flat top.\u201d would have probably passed by without any issues. Lifting words and phrases verbatim is going to get you into some hot water if your creation (which obviously isn\u2019t all created by you) contains direct quotes from other writers. You can get around that mess by contacting the owner of the song(s) and asking for permission, and getting it in writing is a good idea too, to use a line here and there.", "yes, that is copyright infringement which is now allowed", "The question makes no sense as written.\nCopyright is the exclusive right that a creator has to copy, distribute, publish, publicly perform or display, or make derivative works of his or her creative work.\nCopyright infringement is doing that with someone else\u2019s creative work without their permission.\nIf someone is performing or publishing your song \u2014 with or without your lyrics \u2014 without your permission, they are infringing your copyright to that song.", "The most important concept in music copyright law is that each single piece of recorded music involves two distinct rights. The first being rights to protect the underlying music composition \u2014 that is, the specific arrangement and composition of musical notes, chords, rhythm, harmonies, and song lyrics.\nso.. in simpler terms\u2026 yea, it\u2019s copyright"], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Joanna Boules", "view_list": [22, 1, 58, 16]}, "451": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["K H", "Lia Kim", "Chung-Hee", "Chanty Hanke"], "question_title": "Out of all the peoples opinion, which BTS album is the best?", "topic_list": ["The BTS Fandom", "BTS Songs", "Music Albums", "BTS (K-pop group)", "K-Pop", "Music"], "no_of_view": "1,036", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 3, 2, 0], "ans_list": ["LY: Tear or Wings based on most people\u2019s opinions.", "I\u2019ve always said that I don\u2019t really have a favorite BTS album(s), but if I had to choose between them all I would just have to go with the Love Yourself series as a whole (lol a bit of a copout answer i know sorry).\nI mean, can you really blame me?\nI really love the message that is trying to be conveyed with the songs in these albums and think that it\u2019s good for a lot of people and has helped/inspired a lot of people through the stuff that goes on in their lives. It consists of 11 tracks that all differ in terms of genre influences and production, and yet, it successfully formulates a cohesive, magnificent message that raises the issue of love and when it can become toxic, emotional and sad.\nAs RM, the leader of BTS, has said, \u201cLove is a complex and there are sides that really make us feel bad or depressed. "no_of_view": "356", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [2, 0], "ans_list": ["Sure, if you like the way it sounds and feels when you play it, and it\u2019s in your price range, why not?\nA Stradivarius copy isn\u2019t necessarily more valuable or better than any other violin. Since Antonio Stradivari\u2019s time, many, many, many violin makers have made violins using Stradivari\u2019s designs and specifications to some extent and have labeled them as Strad copies. Some of these are exact replicas of famous Stradivarius instruments, meticulously handcrafted by master luthiers, worth tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars, that any professional violinist would be proud to play. Many others were made by lesser craftsmen, good violins worth a few thousand or so. A lot more \u2014 maybe the majority? \u2014 are mass-produced, factory-made student grade instruments, some of which are decent playing and sounding instruments perfectly suited for a beginner, worth a few hundred dollars or so, and some of which are cheap, shoddily made, unplayable violin-shaped objects that are sold exclusively online (because no reputable violin shop will sell them).\nSo simply knowing that a violin is a Strad copy tells you nothing about its maker, age, quality, condition, or sale price. Those are what you need to consider when purchasing a violin.\nGo (in-person if at all possible) to a brick-n-mortar violin shop. Do not go to Guitar Center or Sam Ash or your local guitars-drums-keyboards music store; they won\u2019t have violins and even if they have one or two, they will be cheap crap and the sales people won\u2019t know anything about them anyway. You need a store that specializes in violins and bowed string instruments. Talk to the sales people, let them know how much you\u2019re able to spend (don\u2019t forget \u2014 you need a bow and a case in addition to the violin!) and let them recommend some instruments for you to try out and listen to. You may wind up with a Stradivarius copy \u2014 or a Maggini copy, a Stainer copy, a Guarnerius copy \u2014 that doesn\u2019t matter, as long as you like the sound and feel of it.\nHappy fiddling!!", "If it is a hand-made Stradivarius copy, it will probably play really well, whereas if it is a factory-made copy, your chances of getting a good violin for your money is highly unlikely."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Lily Averette", "view_list": [23, 12]}, "20": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Dannika Esquibel", "Krystal Myst"], "question_title": "Which K-pop idols/groups have similar voices to Shuhua (from GIDLE)?", "topic_list": ["Kpop Girl Groups", "(G)I-DLE (K-Pop group)", "Idol", "K-Pop Idols", "K-Pop Artists and Groups", "Pop Music", "K-Pop", "Music"], "no_of_view": "803", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 1], "ans_list": ["To Me I Don\u2019t Think Any K-Pop Idol Sounds Like Shuhua From (G)-Idle Because She Has A AMAZING VOICE", "I think she is similar to Irene of RED VELVET maybe?"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Kazumi Hatake", "view_list": [13, 22]}, "647": {"no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["U Nice Peeps"], "question_title": "What is the storyline of bts album till date, I am a new army so I don't know much?", "topic_list": ["Storyline", "The BTS Fandom", "BTS Songs", "Music Albums", "BTS (K-pop group)", "K-Pop", "Music"], "no_of_view": "200", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Firstly, Welcome to the fandom dear ARMY!! \ud83d\udc9c\nI'd like you to see this video. Is she still alive and happy?", "Don't know"], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Santosh Jha", "view_list": [14, 45]}, "990": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Luke Hellwyck"], "question_title": "What instruments does Lil Wayne play?", "topic_list": ["Lil Wayne (musician)", "Hip Hop and Rap Artists", "Hip Hop Music", "Music"], "no_of_view": "536", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["The Tortured Cat."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Jose Abarca", "view_list": [13]}, "645": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Claire Uhler"], "question_title": "What are the characteristics of Baroque music how would you describe baroque music?", "topic_list": ["Baroque", "Baroque Music", "Music History", "Music Genres", "Characteristics", "Classical Music", "Music"], "no_of_view": "252", "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["What are the characteristics of Baroque music?\nThe new interest in music\u2019s dramatic and rhetorical possibilities gave rise to a wealth of new sound ideals in the Baroque period.\nContrast as a dramatic element\nContrast is an important ingredient in the drama of a Baroque composition. The differences between loud and soft, solo and ensemble (as in the concerto), different instruments and timbres all play an important role in many Baroque compositions. Composers also began to be more precise about instrumentation, often specifying the instruments on which a piece should be played instead of allowing the performer to choose. Brilliant instruments like the trumpet and violin also grew in popularity.\nMonody and the advent of the basso continuo\nIn previous musical eras, a piece of music tended to consist of a single melody, perhaps with an improvised accompaniment, or several melodies played simultaneously. Not until the Baroque period did the concept of \u201cmelody\u201d and \u201charmony\u201d truly begin to be articulated. As part of the effort to imitate ancient music, composers started focusing less on the complicated polyphony that dominated the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries and more on a single voice with a simplified accompaniment, or monody. If music was a form of rhetoric, as the writings of the Greeks and Romans indicate, a powerful orator is necessary\u2014and who better for the job than a vocal soloist? The new merger between the expression of feeling and the solo singer come through loud and clear in Monteverdi\u2019s preface to the Combattimento di Tancredi e Clorinda from his Eighth Book of Madrigals (1638), in which he writes: \u201cIt has seemed to me that the chief passions or affections of our mind are three in number, namely anger, equanimity and humility. The best philosophers agree, and the very nature of our voice, with its high, low and middle ranges, would indicate as much.\u201d The earliest operas are an excellent illustration of this new aesthetic.\nAlong with the emphasis on a single melody and bass line came the practice of basso continuo, a method of musical notation in which the melody and bass line are written out and the harmonic filler indicated in a type of shorthand. As the Italian musician Agostino Agazzari explained in 1607:\nSince the true style of expressing the words has at last been found, namely, by reproducing their sense in the best manner possible, which succeeds best with a single voice (or no more than a few), as in the modern airs by various able men, and as is the constant practice at Rome in concerted music, I say that it is not necessary to make a score\u2026 A Bass, with its signs for the harmonies, is enough. But if some one were to tell me that, for playing the old works, full of fugue and counterpoints, a Bass is not enough, my answer is that vocal works of this kind are no longer in use.\nBecause basso continuo, or thorough bass, remained standard practice until the end of the Baroque period, the era is sometimes known as the \u201cage of the thorough bass.\u201d\nDifferent instrumental sounds\nAfter being ignored for decades, Baroque music has become increasingly popular over the last fifty years. As part of this new interest, scholars and musicians have spent countless hours trying to figure out how the music might have sounded to 17th and 18th century audiences. While we will never be able to recreate a performance precisely, their work has unearthed several major differences between Baroque and modern ensembles:\npitch: In 1939, modern orchestras agreed to tune to a\u2019=440hz (the note A pitched at 440 cycles per second), which replaced a previously lower pitch (a\u2019=435hz) adopted in 1859. Before 1859, however, there was no pitch standard. The note to which Baroque ensembles tuned, therefore, varied widely at different times and in different places. As a result, the music notated on a score might have sounded as much as a half tone lower than how it would traditionally be performed today. In an effort to allow for this discrepancy, many baroque ensembles adjust their tuning to the repertoire being performed: a\u2019= 415hz for late baroque music, a\u2019=392hz for French music, a\u2019=440hz for early Italian music and a\u2019=430hz for classical repertoire.\ntimbre: While most of the instruments in a baroque ensemble are familiar, there are several prominent members no longer featured in modern ensembles. The harpsichord was the primary keyboard instrument (and an important member of the continuo group), and instruments important in the 16th and 17th centuries like the lute and viol, still continued to be used. Variations in instruments still popular today also gave the baroque ensemble a different sound. String instruments like the violin, viola and cello used gut strings rather than the strings wrapped in metal with which they are strung today, for example, giving them a mellower, sweeter tone.\nperformance technique: A baroque score contains little (if any) information about elements like articulation, ornamentation or dynamics, and so modern ensembles need to make their own informed choices before each performance. Mechanical differences between baroque and modern instruments also suggest that the older instruments would have sounded differently, so ensembles like Music of the Baroque often adjust their technique to allow for this. Because baroque and modern bows are structurally different, for example, string players using modern bows often use a gentler attack on the string and crescendos and diminuendos on longer notes. 17th and 18th century performance treatises also imply that finger vibrato (a technique in which a string player rocks his or her fingertip on the string to enrich the tone) was used sparingly for expressive moments, while bow vibrato (an undulating movement of the bow) was generally preferred."], "date_list": ["Apr 28, 2020"], "question_author": "Bhavin Patel", "view_list": [188]}, "1006": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["Arielle Lim", "Dannika Esquibel", "Neneh Duanda", "Irene Kim"], "question_title": "Why many KPOP artists' MV are posted on Stone Music Entertainment or 1THEK YouTube channel? Everyone can improve their vocal technique, but not everyone can improve to the point where he/she can be considered a good singer. My wife is talented in languages, as is her family, but none of them or she can sing, and I doubt training would change that very much.", "Physical attributes definitely affect the maximum quality of voice and vocal control that can be achieved. That\u2019s an unavoidable fact.\nAside from the physical issues, as with every skill it is possible that some people will learn very quickly and others very slowly. Those who progress slowly when taught often lose interest in practising - and the drive to improve diminishes causing them to give up before they achieve their maximum potential, in which case it is easy to say they found it impossible to be a good singer.\nI have known people whose attempts to pitch a note were hopeless. There seemed to be a complete disconnection between their hearing a note and their ability to control the vocal cords to reproduce the same note. This is sometimes called being \u201ctone deaf\u201d, (which should be \u201cpitch deaf\u201d by the way) but that\u2019s wrong in my opinion. These people might be music lovers. They enjoyed listening to music. If tested, they could tell you if a note was higher or lower than the one before. It\u2019s just that when they sang the note, they couldn\u2019t match the pitch. Some would be convinced they were matching the pitch. Others knew they were way off but didn\u2019t know how to correct.\nTo me, that\u2019s weird. I have to remind myself that some people can\u2019t repeat a word, let alone a note. If you ask them to say a rarely used word like \u201cContrapuntal\u201d they\u2019ll try, but will come out with \u201cContapruntly\u201d or something. Unfamiliar words turn to mush in their heads. Likewise, some people can\u2019t dance - their feet don\u2019t move right even when watching an instructor like a hawk.\nAnd for me, the thing I can\u2019t master and decided to never try again - skating on ice. I can go round and round the rink in circles. I can start, I can steer myself, I can stop. I can manage not to go wobbly and fall over, but that\u2019s the limit. I can\u2019t go backwards although I understand the theory, I can\u2019t do that sideways stopping thing, scraping up a shower of ice over everyone in front (annoying). So I completely understand that the things some people find easy, others can\u2019t master.\nThank goodness we\u2019re all different. That\u2019s what makes it possible to be entertained by someone else\u2019s skill.", "Yes. Some people just don\u2019t have it. Even if it did, it has no firmware to tell it what to do with said data.\nthey only thing putting a CD on a record player would achieve is a scratched CD and a potentially damaged needle.", "Why don\u2019t you give it a try?", "Only in very specific definitions of the word \u201cplay\u201d.\nYou can't listen to music on the CD using a record player because sound on a record is in direct relation to the grooves that is being read by the needle of the player, so the movement of the needle is translated to an electrical signal that represents the music, so it only has to be amplified.\nThe information on a CD is stored in a binary form (0 or 1) by punching small holes that can be read by sending a laser that only reflects a focused light on the receiver when there is no hole (or vice versa). Thid way the receiver can make an electrical binary signal that needs to be translated to create the music. See CD-ROM - Wikipedia\nfor a better explanation.\nThe thing is, when somebody told me that there would be a new music device that reads music by laser, I assumed the laser would read the record thus reducing the wear of the record. I think it would be possible, but much more difficult technically and as it is, a CD is much easier to transport and to handle.", "Yes and no.\nNot a CD by itself.\nI have a Vinyl Disc. It\u2019s media that has a standard CD on one side and a vinyl record on the other. You can see the styrofoam adapter in the middle the converts it to a size that can fit on a record player spindle. They treated songwriting collaboratively and democratically, listing themselves as a band as the authors of their songs. This happened even though lead singer the late Gord Downie in fact wrote most of their lyrics; in fact during live performances he would test drive lyrics which later became album songs. This is one big reason why the band kept their original line up for their entire 30+ year career, and how they kept their friendships alive.
